2 bank suspects caught; 
I shot 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
AUSTIN — Two suspects in 
Monday's Brooks Field National 
Bank robbery were arrested 
Friday by the FBI here. One suspect was shot and is in fair condition at Brackenridge Hos­ pital. 
. 
Jesse Godinez. 27. of Austin u h s ar* rested first by special PBI agents. 
Later. Roberto E Ramirez. 45. of San 
Antonio and Houston, was shot about 4 p.m. while resisting arrest, the FBI said. 
Joseph O’Connell, special agent in charge, said Ram irez was spotted by 
Austin PBI agents in an autom obile near 35o8 Alpine Circle in Austin. 
“ He assaulted the agents by th rea­ tening them with a revolver and in the process of resisting arrest was fired upon by the agents.” O'Connell said. 
R a m ire z w as shot th ro u g h the mouth. O’Connell said. He was first listed in serious condition, but was in fair and stable condition by 8 p.m .. according to hospital officials. 
Charge 

Ram irez is the suspect accused of entering Brooks Field National Bank on Valentine’s Day. dem anding money and e s c a p in g w ith an u n d isc lo se d amount of cash. 

A few hours later. Ramirez was re ­ portedly burned on the face and legs after setting the getaway car on fire, authorities said. 

Godinez was not the person who en­ tered the bank, but assisted Ramirez and drove the getaway car. O’Connell said. 
Godinez was arraigned before U S. 
Magistrate Joseph F. Leonard Jr. He is in Bexar County Jail in lieu of a 
Sal).(MMI bond 
O’Connell sjid Ihe arrests climaxed four days of investigation by the FBI and the San Antonio Police D ep art­ ment. 
Both men are charged with federal bank robbery, which carries a m axi­ mum 25-year sentence. 

By TRUDE B. FELDMAN 
SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
WASHINGTON - On her first day in the White House, Rosa- lvnn Carter cried. 

She was exhausted from standing on her feet all day, shaking hands with thousands of friends, supporters, cam ­ paign w o rk e rs , foreign d ip lo m a ts , congressm en, Cabinet m em b ers and 
Army and Navy brass who had trooped into the East Room, the state dining room, the Red Room, and the Blue

Bonnie and George 
Carmack visit the 
Highland lakes — 
Page IB 

Spur's Silas says his value is limited this yea* — Page ID 

And much, much more 

This article is the result o f an exclusive interview with the First Lad\\ the first interview she has granted since moving into the White House. 

Room to shake hands with her and the new President. And she was cold. 
Her husband, the P re s id e n t, had turned down the thermostat to a chilly 
85 degrees to dram atize the nation’s fuel s h o rta g e —and the F i r s t L ady wasn’t dresvsed for it. 

“ If I hadn't been so tired from all the inaugural festivities,” she told me. 
“ th e cold p ro b a b ly w o u ld n ’t have bothered me so much. I just wanted to be warm and to sit down.” 
So she told Jim m y Carter: “ I just can’t take it.” and her eyes flut'd with 

 tears. The President was sympathetic and brought her an extra sweater but the therm ostat stayed at 85. 
And Rosalyn ii ( a r t e r , as she has done ever since her husband entered politics, put on the e x tra sw e a te r, grinned tilt' tears away and — and in a word — coped 
Coping is something the First Lady docs with class 
Terrified at first at standing up in front of an audience, sin1 learned to be an effective, even forceful, speaker in her husband’s be­ half and became a genuine asset in Ins 

 successful run for the presidency. 
A self-described “ hom ebody” who loves to cook and sew and ca n ' for her husband and children and grandchild, 
Rosalynn Carter has acquired both a deep interest in a dost' knowledge of important public issues ranging from international relations to domestic af­ fairs problems, 
“ Jim m y wants me to be informed on all the issues so FII understand the situations and problems lit' is working on, ” slit' told mc in lier first

WASHINGTON - The White 
House announced Friday it is conducting an intensive and com prehensive review of for­ eign intelligence operations. 

Meanwhile, new reports circulated that the CIA had secret financial rela­ tionships with at least a half-dozen foreign leaders. 
The announcement of the presidoo* tial review was made by press secre­ tary Jody Powell during a briefing to r e p o r te r s in w hich he d ec lin e d to comment on a published report Friday 

 that the CIA has for 2o y e a rs been making secret cash paym ents to King 
Hussein of Jordan 
Powell’s statem ent was tho first of­ ficial indication of th e P r e s id e n t’s concern over CIA aid P itie s and his apparent intention to bring them under control.

H San Antonio E X P R E S S -N E W S — Saturday February 19 1 9 7 7 
Balloonist finishes cross-country flight 

Karl Thomas achieved his goal of setting a cross-country record for travel by hot-air balloon Friday. He reached the Atlantic Ocean 18 days after leaving Arcadia, Calif. 

Sasquatch quest quash requested 

Oregon State Rep. Ted Kulongoski of Junction City go! an unusual autographed picture from a constitu- tent — 
Sasquatch, the legendary 
“ Bigfoot” of the Pacific Northwest. 
“ To T ed,” the inscription read. 
“ Thanks for caring. Love. Sas.” 
The photo cam e with Sasquatch m em orabilia from ‘‘the men and women of North American Wildlife 
R esearch.” T he group is a clear­ inghouse in ‘‘the search for the world's most intriguing mystery .’’ 
Kulongoski offered a resolution la st week to make it unlawful iii O r e g o n to 
“harass, annoy or intim idate” 
Sasquatch. 

T h o m a s, 28, of T ro y , M ich., touched down at 2:3o p.m. on a beach near Fernandina Beach, Fla., north of J a c k s o n v ille , a c c o rd in g to a spokesm an for the com pany that sponsored the flight. ! 
Dave Severson, the spokesman. said Thomas pulled a cord to collapse the orange. 9o-foot-high ‘‘Limited edition Sail.” Thomas then walked to the ocean and splashed himself with water. 
Thomas had been bound for Day­ tona Beach, about 13o miles to the south, for the annual Speed Weeks at 
Daytona International Speedway. 
Prevailing winds, however, forced 
Ins balloon northeastward instead of southeastward, the direction he had hoped for early Friday when he as­ cended from T h u rs d a y n ig h t’s stopping place near Blountstown in 
Florida's Panhandle. lbs flight surpassed publisher 
Malcolm Forbes’ 33-day c r o s s ­ country balloon trip by 13 days, Se­ verson said Forbes made his trip in 
1973. 
Thomas’ 18-day odyssey took him into Mexico and as far north as 
Montana. He had originally planned to fly across the southern half of the 
I luted States, but weak winds forced a change in plans. 
Thomas crashed in the Atlantic 
Ocean in 197fi while trying to fly a helium balloon to Europe. He suf­ fered two broken rills and floated iii the water for several days before being rescued by a ship. 

In defiance of O gden Nash, one of the Phoenix Zoo's resident pelicans proclaims silently that his beak can hold a lot, but not as much as his belly can — AP Wirephoto 
Americans get 
Havana tour 

Rep. 
Jonathan Bingham was in 
Ins pajamas and his wife June was draped in a bath towel in their hotel room in Havana Monday night when there was an unexpected knock at the door. 
The New York Democrat opened the door, “ and it was Fidel Castro,” lie said. “ lh* had thought we would be warned beforehand and he was very em barrassed.” 

Pancake 
Day slated 

The annual m adness called P a n ­ cake Day — actually two days of celebrating the pancake — will begin 
Monday in Liberal, Kan., with a teen-ager trying to improve on his pancake-eating m ark of a year ago. 
David Williams, 18, took the prize last year when he downed 78 pan­ cakes in observance of the bicenten­ nial. He said he will try to eat 77 this year. 
The big event gets under way 
Tuesday with the 28th annual running of the pancake race, with housewives, students and other women running a distance of 415 yards while they flip pancakes. A pancake race is run simultaneously in Olney, England, and the international pancake race winner is determined in a trans-At- lantie telephone cull between the two cities to com pare times. 
Sheila Turner won the race the last two years for Liberal. 

Marital mishmash 

Two interesting things happened to 
Larry Adler, the 83-year-old h a r­ monica virtuoso and composer, in 
London Thursday. He was divorced by his second wife. 
Sally, who testified they had lived apart for more- than two years. 
And Lady 
Selina Hastings, 3o. daughter of the 
Earl of Huntingdon, said she would marry Adler in June. 
“ I am very happy," she said. “ I ve been wailing nearly six years for this m oment.”

Task force clears FBI 

WASHINGTON (AP) - The FBI in­ vestigated Dr. Martin Luther King's death thoroughly and honestly and concluded correctly that J a m e s Earl 
Ray was the lone assassin, a Justice 
D ep a rtm en t task force re p o rte d 
Friday. 
Though mysteries linger in the case, there is no new evidence w arranting further investigation, the task force of five lawyers and two research analysts said. 
Honestly conducted 
“ The task force has concluded that the investigation bv the FBI to ascer­ tain and capture the m urderer of Dr 
Martin Luther King Jr. was thorough­ ly, honestly and s u c c e ssfu lly conducted.” the report said. “ The sum of all of the evidence of Ray s guilt points to him so exclusively that it most effectively makes the point that no one else was involved.’’ 
The task force concluded that v ar­ ious conspiracy theories, including those advanced by Ray himself, are without foundation Ray’s stories are contradictory and self-serving, the report said. 
The FBI, despite its longterm and probably illegal cam paign to harass 
King and discredit him as a civ ii rights 

 leader, generally undertook an a g ­ gressive probe of the m urder of King un a motel balcony iii M em phis on 
Aug. I, 1988, the task force said 
It added that the bureau checked out the conspiracy theories but found nothing to them. 
Hie task force lawyers did find some things to criticize about the FBI probe. 
It said the bureau failed to inves­ tigate leads suggesting that Ray and members of his family were iii touch a fte r his esca p e in 1987 from the 
Missouri state prison and said “ The bureau should have pursued this line of the investigation more thoroughly.” 
It also co m p lain ed th a t the FBI u nder d ire c to r J . E d g a r H oover refused to keep then-Atty. Gen. R am ­ sey Clark and other officials informed about details of the probe. And it said the departm ent failed lo exercise its supervisory authority over the bureau. 
Levi hornier Atty. Gen. Edward ll Levi launched the departm ent review last 
April to determ ine whether the FBI was implicated in the assassination, whether anyone should be prosecuted for the h a ra s s m e n t of K ing, and whether there was evidence requiring a further probe of the assassination.

Mexico’s petrol reserves huge 

MIW VONK TIMES SMVtCt 
MEXICO CITY — Despite conserva­ tive official estimates. Mexico’s oil and natural gas reserves are now privately believed to exceed 8o billion barrels, roughly six times greater than Alas­ ka’s North Slope deposits and much larger than previously estimated. 
The new estimate, which contrasts sharply with the official reserve figure of ll billion barrels announced just two months ago, has been accepted by 
American government and oil industry experts and, more significantly, has been privately confirmed by Mexican officials who in the past were reticent to admit the enormity of the country’s oil wealth. 
Last week. for the first time since oil

WASHINGTON (A P ) - P re s id e n t 
C a rte r on F rid a y w ith d rew the nomination of career diplom at M al­ colm Toon lo be am b assa d o r to the 
Soviet Union — a post Toon now oc­ cupies under a te m p o rary a p p o in t­ ment 
The Slate Departm ent insisted the 
President’s pullback of the nomination was in no way linked with the s u b ­ stance of American-Soviet relations. 
“ This is a routine action taken by every new administration to permit the new Presdent to review the appoint­ m ents of his p red ecesso r,” a S late 
Department spokesman said. “ This is a government-wide pullback of p r e ­ sidential nominations.” 
The action cairn as one of a lengthy list of w ithdraw als of n o m in a tio n s made by former President Gerald R 
Ford duruig his final three weeks in office.

 was struck here in 19o1, daily output exceeded I million barrels, of which 
14o,ooo barrels today are being export­ ed. mainly to the United States. The state oil monopoly. Pemex. has a 1982 production target of 2.2 million b a r­ rels. half of which would be available for export. 
Most of M exico’s new proven r e ­ serves form part or a huge hydrocar* lion basin in the southeastern states of 
C h iap as and T ab asco and offshore from the state of Campeche in the Gulf of Mexico. 
These deposits, discovered less than five years ago, already account for 8o per cent of total output, although fewer than a dozen of an estimated 18o oil- bearing stru ctu res have so far been tapped. 
P riv a te fo re c a sts of even la rg e r probable rese rv e s are based on e n ­ couraging hydrocarbon discoveries in other regions, notably oil at Cotuxla in the Gulf coast state of Veracruz and natural gas near Nuevo Laredo on the 
Texas border and around Sebastian!},

 secret intelligence reports, that the canal issue was a ticking time bomb about to explode. 
President Jim m y Carter gave it top priority after he took charge of foreign affairs. 
He dispatched a crack negotiating team, beaded by the veteran diplomat 
E llsw orth B u n k e r, to P a n a m a this week. 
Its secret instructions are to seek a reasonable form ula that will perm it the United States to relinquish sover­ eignty over this strip of Panam anian territory. 
But there are some flies in the di­ plomatic ointment. 
Ominous cracks have appeared, for example, in the Panam anian economy. 
Dictators habitually try to divert pub­ lic attention from their domestic fai­ lu res by s t i r r i n g up an e m o tio n a l issue. . 
There is concern that Panam a s m i­ litary dictator, O m ar Torrijos, might forego a reasonable settlement and use the canal as a political issue. 
Carter’s pledge 
President Carter, for his part, has pledged to resto re m orality to U.S. foreign policy and to take a stand ag a in st n atio n s that a b u s e hu m an rights. 
He has just received a confidential report from Rep. John M urphy, D- 
N.Y., about torture under Torrijos. 
Murphy pointedly urged the presi­ dent not to s u r r e n d e r the P a n a m a 
Canal until the alleg atio n s 
....... have been cleared up. 
T he d is t u r b in g re p o rt, w ritte n and tr a n s l a te d in 
Panam a under extrem e d u r­ ess, was smuggled out of the country. 
Some of its allegations have 
— been confirmed by diplomatic sources. 
The report ch arg es that T o rrijo s’ political opponents have been shot, drowned, beaten, sexually abused and electrically shocked. 
It names 
32 people who allegedly have been m u r­ dered by the Torrijos government. 
One example 
F o r e x a m p le , a R om an C ath o lic priest. Hector Gallegos, was arrested by the Panam anian National Guard in 
June 1971. 

He had been organizing agricultural cooperatives in his impoverished par­ ish. 

Apparently, he found himself work­ ing against the interests of some local relatives of the Panam anian dictator. 

D iplom atic so u rce s confirm that 
G allegos h as not been h eard from since. 

“ The usual pattern,” states the re­ port. “ is that a person is arre ste d without a w arrant and without accusa­ tion. and then the authorities deny any knowledge of their whereabouts. 
“ Sometimes the victim is released after questioning or torture or both. and sometimes nothing more is heard about the victim .” 

The state police seldom allow rela­ tives to cla im the v ic tim s ’ abused bodies. 
But the re p o rt alleg e s th a t four bodies — those of stu d en t M arlene 
M endizabal, student Dorita Moreno, lawyer Ruben Miro and Eduardo White 
— w ere recovered and showed ev i­ dence of torture. 
No individual rights 
T h ere are no individual rights in 
P a n am a w here, the report alleges, 
“ the unwarranted search of homes by the m ilita ry police is an ev ery d ay happening.” The report includes affi­ davits and details about the torture that is inflicted. 

It also charges, as we reported in 
1973, that m em bers of Torrijos’ family aud high Panam anian officials are in­ volved in in te rn a tio n a l n a rc o tic s smuggling. 
Delicate talks 
These allegations could upset the delicate negotiations for a new P ana­ ma Canal treaty. . 
A Panam anian Embassy spokesman said the charges were fabricated by

 who supported him. , 
He was very grateful, he wrote, that the senators had let the committee and,

Added Long: “ You will not be dis­ appointed." 
A spokesm an for the senator was aghast at the thought that Long might be hinting he will return the favor from his well-oiled resources. 
Chimney waste 
A small device that could cut resi­ dential gas consumption by 2o per cent to 3o per cent is being kept off the market by the American Gas Associa­ tion. 
The inexpensive device could save our energy-starved nation the equiva­ lent of 5oo.ooo barrels of oil a day. 
The M ichigan C on so lid ated G as 
Company has developed the device, which costs about S35 to install in old furnaces. , 
One part restricts the size of the flue. tile other reduces the flam e in over­ sized furnaces. 
Bulverde to organize 
CB patrol 

A citizens band radio mobile patrol is being organized in Bulverde to fight a recent rash of robberies in the com ­ munity. 
Meetings will be held Sunday and 
Wednesday at Bulverde to organize a neighborhood watch p ro g ra m , said 
Jerry Smith, crim e prevention specia­ list for the Alamo Area Council of 
Governments. 
During the last week. Smith was asked by Comal School District and 
Comal Sheriff’s Department to address a citizens’ meeting at Bulverde Middle 
School. 
Smith told an audience of 33 persons about improving home security and the usefulness of Operation Identifica­ tion, w hereby citizens have th e ir names engraved on their property. 
The meetings and the neighborhood watch program are an effort to bring order to the community following the robberies and so citizens will not feel the need to carry arms, Smith said

B reakup plan for E dw ards m ight be illegal 

By DAVID HENDRICKS 
A proposal to split a state protective order over the Ed­ wards aquifer was called p o ssi­ bly illegal Friday by a stale of­ ficial in the attorney general’s office in Austin. 
And Mayor Lila Cockrell issued a statem ent F riday stating her d isa p ­ pointment that the Texas Water Quali­ ty Board staff has recommended split­ ting the present single order into se­ ven. separate county orders. 
Report 

The responses from Mayor Cockrell and Troy Webb, head of tin' attorney general's environmental division, fol­ lowed release of a TWQB report sum ­ m a riz in g te stim o n y ta k e n at an 
Uvalde public hearing in January. 
“ We are in disagreem ent with the 
J TWQB) hearing exam iner’s report.” 
Webb said. “ We will be at the board meeting March 3 (in Austin) to say it will be unwise and might be illegal to enforce seven orders over what is in effect one underground body of w ater that does not have any resp e ct for county lines.” 

At the Uvalde hearing. Alamo An'a 
Council of Governments Executive Dir. 
Al Not/on reported Webb’s concern the proposal s adoption may have the ('it­ ll re protective order struck down as discriminatory by the Courts. 
TWQB Executive Dir. Hugh Yantis. who has proposed the change, replied he was aware of tilt' contention. 
The TW QB rep o rt to th e b o ard m em bers, however, makes no mention of Not/on's rem ark s on possible dis crimination. 
No statement 
TWQB attorney Lee M athews said the attorney g e n e r a l’s office never submitted a statement at the hearing or since then on the matter. 
Mathews said Ins report was only a sum m ary and not a transcript of the hearing, and he thought other rem arks by Not/on we're more important. 
Mathews concludes the report with the recommendation the TWQB di­ rectors adopt individual county orders at their March 3 meeting. 
H ow ev er, m ost of the testim o n y sum m arized in the report is against the change. 
Uvalde and Kinney county officials testified iii favor the change, but nu­ merous Bexar County officials and re-

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
EXPRESS N E W S M i D K A l W R IIIR 

Trainees at Lackland AFU arc nut experiencing an epidemic of llong 
Kong flu, a base spokesman said Friday. 
Iii fact, trainees are not experiencing any kind of epidemic, flu or otherwise, the spokesman added. 
B ase Inform ation O fficer Ll. Col. 
J i m J o n e s m a d e Ins c o m m e n ts i i i reaction to television news report aired 
Thursday that a Hong Kong flu epide­ mic had broken out at Lackland. 
“ There has been a mild outbreak of a flu-like infection among trainees thai resembles the symptoms of Hong Kong flu.” Col. Jones said 

Small outbreak 
“ But it has been a very sm all out­ break. affecting only about 18o trainees out of a population of 1o,ooo." 
“ We began giving inoculations last 
W ednesday and have c a n c e lle d all mass meetings and all off-base liberty for train ees te m p o rarily , Just to be sure.” ( ol Jones said

UVALDE — Zavala County officials 
— iii an lith hour move — late Friday agreed to pay disputed lax funds for 
Southwest Texas Junior College lo the 
38th District Court. 
Bist. Judge Jack Woodley said lie talked with Zavala County Atty. Pablo 
Avila, who said some $2o,(MKI iii funds will he delivered here not later than next Wednesday. The college is located in Uvalde. 
Woodley said he had agreed to an extension of tim e until then 
Woodley had ordered Zavala County 
Judge Jose Angel Gutierrez, county commissioners and oilier county offi­ cials to have a total of $28 (IOO iii dispute into the registry of the* court not later than Saturday. 

Not guilty 

At a h ea rin g last week. Woodley found tile officials not guilty of con­ tempt charges. 
The hearing resulted from a lawsuit filed by the junior college d istric t, which covers Edwards, Real, Uvalde and Zavala counties. The plaintiff [iud filed a motion for contem pt and in­ junctive relief. 
The district filed the lawsuit in J a n ­ uary. Woodley said it will be tried on 
Us merits alxiut March IL 
The district clerk s office here said 
Friday afternoon Zavala County bud only sent $8,3oo of the $28,IHM! 
The suit stem m ed from a move by 
Zavala County Commissioners Court to raise the c h a r g e for collection of pro­ perty taxes a n d delinquent taxes iii that county for the junior college district.

Twins enjoying life 

By MK H VKL 
QHN'I ANILLA 

For tin' past 25 yours. 
Ronnie and Donnie (in- 
Iv oil have survived as 
Siamese twins — p o s s i­ bly the only male Sia­ mese twins living tojjay, aeeording to their stepmother. Mrs. Wesley 
Calyon. 
The twins, featured on the midway of the Joe 
Freem an 
Coliseum grounds during the run of the San Antonio Stock 
Show and Rodeo, were born in Duvton, Ohio on 
Oft. 28. 1951. 
They are joined at the 
('lid of the breastbone by a cartilage, and are con­ nected from this point to 

"ll e Vc as human as e veryb od y else and alive as everybody else. Just because we're different doesn t mean we re not human' 

 the abdomen, lacing each other. 
They share a common navel, descending colon, one bladder aud one set of male organs, though each has h is ow ii kidney. 
They are normal in every other aspect — two arms and two legs — and full of life, love, and lots of personality as they discussed their lives as a rarity — not an oddity . 
Since the age of three. 
Ronnie and Donnie have been 
“ show-biz 

 personalities"' playing stock shows, festivals, shopping c e n t e r s , and county fairs in the Coifed 
States. Venezuela. Mexi­ 

 c o . 
Puerto Rico, and 
( amnia. 
“ We're in show busi­ ness. making a living, earning our w ay," 
Ronnie, the larger of the two young men said. 
The first 2o months of their lives was spent in the hospital undergoing 
X-ray and observation treatments tor the p o s s i­ 

 bility of an operation to separate them 
Two years later their parents decided against the operation when they found the twins had less than a 
5o per cent chance of surv ival if se­ paration was attempted. 
Death 
Separation would have meant death for one and probably for both, spe­ cialists predicted. 
“ Me and Donnie are lucky to be alive. Being 

JOSHES 

M A UNIT OF ALLIED STORES 

DIAMOND 
JOSHES

Windsor Park. 

Illustration enlarged to show detail. 
SALON 

 alive is just the best th in g ." said Ronnie, making sure he was identified correctly. 
Donnie, who claims to be six seconds older, in­ terjected. “ We’re as hu­ man as everybody else and alive as everybody else. Just because we’re different doesn’t mean we’re not human.’’ 
The twins walk in a side straddle with ease. 
They sit. stand and move like clockwork — with precision, grace and unison, never consulting the other about what to do or w here to go next 
During conversation, many times Donnie will start a sentence and 
Ronnie will finish it. sensibly. 
They often speak sim ultaneously, som etimes saying the same thing. 

Read thoughts 
“ I guess sometimes we know what the other is thinking or w e’ll just start talking at the same time, saying, sometimes,, the same thing,’’ Ronnie said 
Sleeping isn’t difficult for the twins. They start out with Ronnie lying on his back and Donnie on a larger pillow lying on his stomach. 
Later in the night, they turn and sleep on their sides. Donnie said. 
As far as clothing is concerned, shirts are never a problem but a pants pattern has been designed for them with four legs and an elastic waistband. Donnie con­ tinued. 
Working on carnival midways about nine months of the year, they travel in a specially con­ structed house trailer w itll a glass wall that opens into the side of their show tent whenever they stop and set up. 
But while traveling is the m ajor interest the twins share, they are very different personal­ ities. 
Ronnie enjoys westerns 

RELAXING with their stepmother, Mrs. M ary Galyon, are Donnie, left, and 
Ronnie Galyon, 2 5 -year-old Siamese twins bTA” PHOTO BV STm CAMPKLl 

 and Donnie wrestling program s. 
Ronnie suffers from epilepsy and 
Donnie has a problem with migrane headaches. 
And they sometimes don’t eat the same meals and one would like to stay up later or go to bed ear­ lier. 
All this boils down to a lot of compromising, 
Ronnie said. “ We have learned to compromise. to take care of each other and just make it easier for both of us,’’ he said. 
Traveling as much as they do, the twins have not had much of a chance for a formal edu­ cation. They have had private tutoring, but claim they have had an education just from traveling and meeting people. 
Always the center of attention in public, 
Ronnie and Donnie said they take the stares and som etim es cruel c o m ­ 

 ments in stride 
Do they ever resent people staring at them or asking stupid questions? 
No resentment 
“ No, we’re used to it, just like we’re used to facing each other, traveling — just like you’re used to doing your job,” Ronnie said. 

I f they could be separ­ ated — into separate in­ dividual bodies right now . would they want it? 
Ronnie answered first 
“ We look at it like this, let God separate us. It was God’s will to make us like this. 
Donnie interrupted 
“ Me and Ronnie would have to learn how to re-do 

 everything — all over again. We would have to learn how to walk, eat, sleep, maybe even think and talk ” 
They both agreed they would never want to be separated and that life for them, conjoined, is just as normal to them as life is for the average human being.

Lopez Portillo to start tourism safety program 

C O M P ILE D F R O M w i r e SERVICES 
W A SH IN G T O N — The Am erican 
Automobile Assn sa>s Mexican Presi­ dent Jose Lopez Portillo has agreed to a wide-ranging program to improve the safety and convenience of Am eri­ cans dri\ ing in Mexico. 
At the same time. Lopez Portillo and 
President ( arter issued a joint com­ munique in which it was announced 
( arter has extended to Mexico almost the same special relationship with the 
I S that Has agreed on last year with 
Brazil, largest and richest of the Latin nations. 
AAA president Jam es ( real said 
Lopez Portillo promised him during a meeting that Mexico would implement recommendations from the AAA and the Mexican minister of tourism within two weeks. 
Warning 

Last December, the State Depart­ ment. at the urging of the AAA. warned Am erican tourists to avoid certain areas of the western Mexican states of Baja California and Sinaloa 

 because of bandit attacks. 
According to the State Department. 
18 Americans have been assaulted by bandits in that area since May and at least three have died. One of those shot to death was David Crawford of San 
Antonio. 
Lopez Portillo reportedly agreed to: 
• 
Estab lish m en t of a national emergency hotline manned by b ilin­ gual authorities. 
• Development of training programs for customs officials and police and adoption of national standards for handling tourist arrests and deten­ tions. . 
• 
Almost complete elimination of customs inspections at international airports and border crossings

Man, 747 killed in road mishap 

An elderly pedestrian died Friday night after being struck by a car on a darkened Northwest road 
Police identified the victim as Rafael 
Sanchez. 74. of 92B S. Laredo St 
The accident reportedly occurred shortly after 7 p m oil the 11141o access road near Fredericksburg Road 
The driver of the westbound car was identified by officers as Harold Her­ man Hun/ dr . 42, of 2o2 Northhaven 
Drive 

Witnesses told police the victim stepped out iii front of the vehicle. 
Sanchez was thrown onto the hood of tin* vehicle and then into the wind­ shield 'lie was earned about OO lect before the car managed to stop, police said 
Sanchez was then thrown about 4o feet, police said 
The elderlv man was rushed to Bex­ ar County 
Hospital where he was pronounced dead at S 22 p.m.

MH/MR plan hit by Reeves 

Rep. Frank Madia's proposal to place Bexar 
County Mental Health/Mental Retardation pro­ grams under state control could spell a $484.(Mill cut in county funds from those services 
‘I! the state takes over these services, t li ev can fund them." said Bexar County Judge Blair Reeves 
Friday. “ I think it would be a serious thing." 
Madia Wednesday asked the Legislative Budget 
Board to explore which of the county's MH/MR programs could be transferred to the San Antonio 
State Hospital on an outreach basis. 
It the county's funds are cut from tilt* program . that could lead to a cut in services — unless the state beefs up its funds. Judge Reeves said. 
The MH/MR board is made up of appointees from several governmental agencies in Bexar County, 
Reeves said he thought Commissioners Court would cut local money if local control was cut 
The .judge sent a letter to Com 
Albert Busta­ mante. who also heads the M H/M R Board, detailing where the $484.out) fund cut could lie 
That $484,(1(111 includes money for this fiscal year and projections for the next fiscal year 
A feud has been running between Madia and the local MH/MR board since last summer 
Madia last summer said the board was mis­ spending money. 
This week Madia said he was requesting inquiry into which programs could be transferred to state supervision because the MH/MR board had been unresponsive.

EDITORIALS

M a n a g in g Editor 
Carter challenges 
Soviets on treaty 

President ( arter is a dave 

 with steal Willis. 
( sin,i* the leverage al' the 

Helsinki 
Accords on 
Human 

.Rights ol‘ 1975, Mr. ( arter has repeatedly spoken up for those rights for all persons. He has broken the linkage theory of 
Henry-Kissinger that made the former Secretary of State timid about internal conditions in 
Russia lest he upset Kremlin lenders about all other topics of 
American interest. 
The unprecedented letter 

 from Mr. Carter to Andrei I). 
Sakharov is remarkable for se­ veral reasons. 
The letter was sent through 

 the C. S. Embassy in Moscow with the knowledge of Secretary of State Cyrus Vance. It was a deliberate move with ample time to (‘valuate likely results. 
The letter was released in 

Moscow by Sakharov, a leading nuclear physicist there. Sakhar­ ov is the Soviet Union's sharpest critic at the moment and he is, 

 iii effect, challenging his go­ vernment to respond to dis­ senters there who are pleading for implementation of the terms of the Helsinki accords. 
The Kremlin took immediate 

 umbrage at the Carter letter. 
That was anticipated. The letter was in response to one written to the President by Sakharov and it included this phrase, “ We shall use our good offices to seek the release of prisoners of cons­ cience (a title adopted by Soviet political prisoners), and we will continue our efforts to shape a 

 world responsive to human aspirations in which nations of differing cultures and histories eau bvt' side-by-side in peace and justice." 

That phrase was iii response 

 to Sakharov's plea for help to get the release of three dissi­ dents in Sov jet jails. Because the Helsinki accords, signed by the Soviets and the I . S. and other nations at the European 
Conference on Security and 
Cooperation, guarantee tin* free interchange of people and ideas, the Carter letter is a bold de­ claration that the American 
President takes the treaty terms seriously. 

Mr. Carter has embraced the 

 detente concept. He has nomin­ ated Paul C. Warlike to nego­ tiate arms limitations with the 
Soviets. Warlike* is regarded by 
Senate hard-liners as dovish. 
That is the soft side* of 

.Iimmv Carter. 
The insistence upon 

 fundamental concern for human rights in all foreign relations is a Carter pledge and it would be a mistake to believe In* will ea­ sily abandon it. It is our judg­ ment that the Kissinger ap­ proach was considered by the 
Soviets to be a weak spot. 
Whatever tin* perceptions, if 

 the Soviets won t honor the hu­ man rights treaty, it will be dif­ ficult to take seriously their word on other matters 
Mr 

Carter has made the challenge in human terms. We expect urn to hold the line. 

Take-or-pay gas contracts need new element of restraint 

A Texas Railroad Commis­ sion order this week aims at easing tin* pain of miscalculat­ ing supply-demand gas orders under iake-or-pay contracts. 
One of the problems has been 

 purchasers el gas. stuck with take-or-pay contracts, have been bad weather forecasters. 

Since gas is iii high demand. users tend to guess high and hope they won t be too far off. 
But under take-or-pay contracts, the distance off target can add up to a lot of money. 
Tilt* new order will use as a 

 base figure for deliveries both purchaser nominations and pro­ ducer forecasts. If performance shows tin* two sets of figures to be significantly out of tolerance, actual performance for the prior 

A way to gel 

It is the weed season and 

 complaints have started to be heard. 
Tilt* City has authority to get 

 weeds cut and it should spread the word now that weed-choked areas will be cleaned up — for a price. Usually, city crews mow lots and bill the landowner — or add the expense to the tax bill. 

W eeding season seem s to be a good t line* for a n o th e r and 

 too 
And this is Freddie, Mr. President 
. . Say “ Hello,” Freddie. . 
He’d like to say hello. 
Delay bond 

Sir I ani UMI per cent for improving tho teaching of our public school chil­ dren. but I am fearful of tho conse­ quences that may occur if the $49 million bond issue of the San Antonio 
Independent School District passes. 
Those bonds prov ide for the air-con­ ditioning of about r»r» schools in addi­ tion to the schools already with air­ conditioning. 
I quote from the Express (Feb. 7): 
“ This winter's natural gas shortage iii the Eastern two-thirds of the nation may In* followed by an electricity shortage that will hit Texas within the year.” 
With skyrocketing costs of energy and the strong possibility of the Arab nations’ abruptly increasing the* price of oil. cost of utilities could get so high that schools with air-conditioning may have to be closed 
I believe the prudent tiling to do is to 
I inst pone the present proposed bond issue for a year or more 
Another reason for the postponement t" that there I" a strong possibility that fluid" for school construction will ln> available in the very near future from the "tate and federal governments to supplement local monev

Allen backed on sentiments 

Sir: I wish to add my support to sentiments expressed by Dr. .limply 
Allen (Jan. 29). I am gratified that he has reaffirmed and reminded us that 
“ Christ's message centered in redir­ ecting the energies of destructive lives." 
If we are to seriously attempt crime prevention, we should start with the juveniles, rile chairperson of the Tex­ as Youth Council. Mrs Eat Avers, and her Ixia rd and every single one of those dedicated men and women on that agency need our total support so that the funds they need to carry on their work is not denied them 
A few minutes of conversation with any of those counselors, superv isors or board members will convince any one of the necessity to establish communi­ ty-fras*d-correct ions facilities for these youngsters 
M >t young people do not start as archcriminal* — they start nut as misguided, “ mis-parented” . or neg­ lected "tatu" offenders Placing them rn a correctional facility with the known juvenile offenders is like inten-

 exercise of power that is availa­ ble. Hanna's proposal would broaden the power within prac­ tical limits. th e w eeds cu t 

 more useful program. Uity and county could sponsor weed-cut­ ting crews and prov ide summer jobs. Crews could be made available at agreeable rates.

JCS fights GI benefit cuts 

WASHINGTON - Tim Joint 

Chiels el Stall (.ICS) appar­ ently are alarmed over attacks zeroing in on military pay and associated benefits. 
They have confronted incoming 
Defense Secretary Harold Brown with a stiff memorandum detailing tor the first time the full extent of post-Vietnam slashes inflicted on armed services compensation and 
|M*rquisltes 
The JC S memorandum is under­ stood as a warning shot not only to 
Brown but to the powerful Office ol 
Management and Budget (UM H). which has often favored slashing service benefit*, and. behind Brown and OMI), lo t undrest 

S e n s i b le

< (ingress aud the public are now aware, as never before that inst over hail of a rising defense Prided i g * 

 per cent in the forthcoming fiscal year) goes to expenses associated 
With people

((til as targets for possible cuts and has (Huntedly asked whether what the military gets ‘ exceeds the lair value of their sen lees

Problem of aliens was not discussed 

WASHINGTON - The new president of Mexico, Jose Lopez 
Portillo, and President Carter had a useful and even amiable 
\ isit here over the last few days. 

This first state occasion for both of them, however, is a reminder of the poverty of power — of how little even the most influential politicians can do lo relieve the basic problems of two such friendly but different neighboring states. 
When Lopez Portillo discussed 
I'.S.-Mexican relations with President 
Gerald Ford a while ago. Ford ended their meeting by saying this was all very interesting and he hoped the 
Mexican president would say the same thing to Ford’s staff. 
More attentive 
(’arter was apparently more atten­ tive and practical. 
Lopez Portillo said before he left that 
“ ( arter has the gift of seeing the problems of finance, trade, technology and immigration in relation to one an­ other,” and ( arter committed himself personally to review the work of the joint U.S.-Mexican study commission and meet regularly to analyze the problems that have divided the two countries. 
But even so, these friendly conver­ sations did not get at the brutal facts. 
For the history of nations is not de­ termined by their leaders, except when they go to war. 
In general these days history is influenced more by tin' private actions of millions of people — by the poverty of the human mind and particularly by the fertility of the human body. 
Basic problem l ins is the basic problem between the United States and Mexico. 
Carter and Lopez Portillo saw it as a common concern of the hemisphere, and not as a conflict between the capi­ talist and the Third Worlds, as it was seen by former President Luis Eehe- verria of Mexico. 
They agreed on ways to ease it through better terms of trade for 
Mexico, through credits from the In­ ternational Monetary Fund and from the World Bank whose President Ro­ bert McNamara “ filled me with enth­ usiasm.” Lopez Portillo said. 
But they cannot really deal with the long-range problems so long as Mexi­ co's population growth outruns its in­ dustrial and agricultural production and its ability to produce jobs at liv ing wages for the millions of Mexicans who are entering the United States illegal­ ly. 
Not explored 

Again tins problem was mentioned iii the talks between the two presidents but not really explored. 

When President Lopez Portillo was born m 192(1. the population of Mexico was 14.SCHUMM. It is more than HS mil­ lion today. It is now increasing by over two million a year compared to the natural increase (births over deaths) of 1.24o,WM) a year in the United States. 

Feheverria told me a few months ago that Mexico’s population would be 
125 million to 127 million by the end of the century. 

President Lopez Portillo, questioned on this in our conversation, said that over a million Mexican women of child-bearing age were now involved in family-planning programs, and that the population would be nearer to HO million or 12o million by the year 2»MM) 
Not U.S. business 

What the Mexicans do with their population, of course, is none of our business — until they cross the U.S. iwirder. 
But with no effective social security or unemployment insurance, half the work force unemployed or under-em­ ployed and inflation running at about 
JO per cent, illegal (or to use the polite word “ undocumented” ) Mexicans, ac­ cording to the I S. Labor Department, now number about eight million, more than the total number of U.S. unem­ ployed — and Eat iii American experts at the State Department put the illegal alien figure nearer IO million. 
In a country that was prepared to do it* own work and pay attention to what s happening to it. this would Im* a howling political crisis, but ifs only recently that the politicians have be­ gun to realize that in the past year the aliens entering the United States, most of them illegally, probably outnum­ bered the natural increase of our own population, 
This problem is getting beyond the control of presidents, 
It is a primary concern of the un­ employed and the unions, and the 
Congress of the United Slates I asked 
President Lopez Portillo whether he noticed a little sign on President 
Carter** desk in the Oval Office. 
“ O God, thy sea is so great and m,v 
Ixia! is so small.” 
No. lie said, but it was true: All pres­ idents could do was to try to guide the bual **It I* not a mailer of the effort of 
.(•ne man alone," Lopez Portillo said iii hi* inaugural address, “ but a feat we must all achieve together.” 
Still, the two president* didn't really get down to Bu* illegal invasion from 
Bu* South or the economic aggression 
(rom the North 
Ate were just truing to get to know out anotto t he saki 
Mavis next time,

Mrs. O’Hair wants no prayer 

The o d d s m a k e r s wouldn't jjive her a p ra y e r ot a chance in her bid For th e A u s tin City 
C ouncil. B u t. th e n M a d a ly n

That notorious atheist — so m eti m es called th e most hated w om an in the world, s o m e ti m e s just ref erred to as 
“ that kook" — only wants the chance 
T he City Council needs an honest person on it.” explains the 57-year-old woman, who settled in Austin a decade

O’Hair says she knows the issues.

K she a publicity hound?

Atheist (’cuter in Austin She says the publicity she g ets is " a d r o p in the bucket." 

Then she puts on the black glasses that hang around her neck and st arts r u m m a g i n g through stack s of p ap ers for som eth ing to illustrate her point.

Madalyn Murray O'Huir — with her

MEW VORK TIMES SERVICE 
WASHINGTON - In addition to making clan­ destine ( ash payments to 
King Hussein of Jordan, the 
United 
S tate s , through the Central In­ telligence Agency, has given cash directly to a number of other foreign leaders in return for fa­ 

 vors over the years, in­ telligence officials said 
Friday. 
Those listed as past recipients included P re ­ sidents Chiang Kai-shek of the N ati o n a li s t g o ­ v e r n m e n t on T a i w a n . 
Ramon Magsa.vsay of the 
P h ilip p in e s . S y n g m a n 
Rhee of South Korea. 

Se se Seko M obutu of 
Zaire. 
E d u a r d o 
F re i 
Montalvo of Chile and 
Ngo Dinh Diem of South 
Vietnam. 
In addition, the offi­ cials said, ca^h payments had been made for var­ ious p e rio d s to 
Luis 
Echeverria when he was interior minister of Mex- 
CIA FI NDS 

< opt inn ed I r o m P a g e IA national leaders who had secret finan­ cial relationships with the CIA. 
Tile hook, “ The CIA and the ( ult of 
Intelligence.” by Victor Marehetti, a former CIA official, and John Marks, a former State Department officer, was published with the names of the reci­ pients deleted, said sources familiar with the original manuscript. The de­ letions were ordered in federal district court as a result of the CIA civil suit. 

The Dalai Lama, the exiled god-king of Tibet, was on the (TA payroll for some time after he fled to India in 1959 to escape the Communist 
Chinese takeover of Tibet. He is equivalent lo the Pope to an estimated (I million Ti­ betans. It is also not known if these payments continue. 
Such payments are not the only focus nf the review announced by Powell 
Friday. Sources said the review is a sweeping look al the current o p e ra­ tions of all intelligence agencies 
“ It’s not inst to see what is proper.” one source said. “ It is a question of whether the operations are worth the money . . . ifs a budget review also." 
Powell said th e review of intelli­ gence activities would also involve senior officials from the Office of 
Management and Budget 
At the same time, the sources said that the review will not he another at­ te m pt in the w o rd s of one-of the sources, to “ dig back into the past and find all the skeletons and wave them around . . . the President (inst) wants lo know w b a t 's h a p p e n i n g on his watch.” 
Decisions 
Powell said Friday iii his prepared statement the review of intelligence activities involves all senior national security officials and it began “ almost from tile first day of the adm inistra­ tion. 
“This review is nearly completed.” 
Powell said, “ and, on the basis of its findings, the President will make basic decisions concerning the future of such activities.” 
Powell added. “ The objective'of the review is to m ak e certain that ac ti­ vities are proper, to ensure full com­ pliance with oversight procedures by law. and that what can he done openly is not done secretly.” 
As a m atte r of policy Powell said that he would not comment “ either to confirm or deny — any stories con­ cerning alleged covert activities.” 
In his session with reporters, the press secretary doggedly refused to elaborate on his opening statement. At times during the sensitive briefing the questioning grew tense and Powell ap­ peared to he groping for words. 
Sources said P resident C a rter o r ­ dered the Hussein payments stopped this week within a day of learning of them. 
In addition, reliable congressional sources said the President has already stopped several other CIA activities and reported their termination to the 
Senate Intelligence Committee. 
Authoritative sources said the pay­ ments to Archbishop Makarios were made at the time the United States. 

 with the tacit consent of the neutralist 
Cypriot president, flew U2 reconnais­ sance mis sions to the Middle East from the British sovereign base of Ab­ rotin on the southern end of the island. 
The CIA also maintained special r a ­ dios near the northern seacoast town of 
Kyrenia to monitor radio communica­ tions from nea rby countries in the eastern Mediterranean. 
Cypriot officials have privately ack­ nowledged the receipt of special U.S. governm ent funds by Makarios hut m a in ta in ed they w ere used by the archbishop for official governmental purposes. 
Gull* Coast group does it up bi” 

Gulf Coast Day committee members swept into the Family Center at Joe 
Freeman Coliseum Friday with the energy of a coastal hurricane and soon transformed the special days booth into a top attraction of the day. 
With Billy Zwersehke as the day’s chairman and J im Wilson of the Port 
Lavaca/Calhoun County Chamber of 
Commerce as his top assistant, the 
(•((ast group had exhibits of industry, samples of broiled shrimp and attrac­ tive samples of natural life as visitor lures. 
One section of the exhibit was fur­ nished by Union Carbide. This had samples of both low and hard density pellets made from natural gas at the firm's plant at Seadrift. 
Overjoyed 
The s a m e p a r t of the booth had flashlights, plastic hags, batteries and many other items made from the pel­ lets. Young people were overjoyed to get a combination reflector and spin­ ner for their bicycles The gadgets were made from the high density pel­ lets. 
The exhibit hit a tem p o rary snag when Joe Surovik. Extension Service marine biologist, had to rush out and buy an aquarium for the marine life in the exhibit. Two aquariums were bro* ken when his pickup truck blew a tire on the way to San Antonio from Port 
Lavaca. 
A panel showed pic tures and had samples of some of the county's agri­ cultural products. 
M a rga ret Rhule. Calhoun County extension demonstration agent, used microwave ovens to prepare shrim p and rock shrimp for the visitors. The rock shrimp are caught off the Yuca­ tan coast of Mexico. 
Nets, ropes and palm fronds gave a rustic touch to the exhibit 
An Alcoa exhibit showed the bauxite ore as it is received at Point Comfort, the refined product and an ingot of aluminum. 
Some of the visitors got instruction from Howard Hartzog on the devilling of the rock shrimp. 

 leo. Carlos Andres Perez when he was in terio r minister of Venezuela. 
Gen. P h ao S riva nond when he was police chief of Thailand and Holden 
Roberto, leader of the 
National Front for the liberation of Angola. 
“ You name 'em and they got money,” said a former U.S. ambassador familiar with the c l a n ­ destine payments 
I example 
Roberto, for example, received an annual r e ­ tainer of $1o.(HH) from the 
CIA from I BH I until the conclusion of the Angolan civil war last year in re­ turn for supplying intel­ ligence r e p o r t s to the agency. “ It was what we called ‘look-in money,’” an ag e n cy official r e ­ called. 
Harrison M. Symmes, who was am bassador to 
Jordan from 1967 to 197o, said he had long opposed overall 
U.S. policy toward Jordan, which he found to he opposed to the “ dynamic forces” of the Arab world, but a d ­ ded that he was not op­ posed to covert payments as such. 
Tin* practice of making clandestine payments to foreign leaders is proba­ bly as old as tin* intelli­ gence profession itself, according to students of espionage. 
While neither confirm­ ing nor denying the r e ­ ports of p a y m e n t s to 
Hussein, Ray S. Cline, a former Deputy Director of the CIA said: 
“ I find it s o m e w h a t hypocritical or naive to assume it wrong for the 
United States to be able to provide financial a s ­ sistance to friendly poli­ tical l e a d e rs o v e r s e a s who are willing in return to provide inform ation 

 bearing on our security as well as their s e c u r i­ ty.” 
“ I regard it as a m o r­ ally d e fe n sib le p h i l o ­ sophy of covert political action.” Cline concluded. 
Old stuff 
A retired agency offi­ cial familiar with the co­ vert payments said: “ It is mostly old stuff going back to th e 194os and 
195os when people were poor.” 
In the rase of the CIA and Jordan the practice began in 1957 after B ri­ tain withdrew from poli­ tical and m i l i t a r y i n ­ volvement in the Hshr- mite Kingdom. 
Hussein’s grandfather. 
King Abdullah, had been a recipient of clandestine 
British p a y m e n ts from the time he was an emir under British protection in 1922 until his a s s a s ­ sination in 1951. British pa y m e n ts continued to 
Hussein. 
‘‘We just pic ked up w h ere the B ritish left off,” said a former U.S. a m b a s s a d o r to Jo rd an . 
‘‘It w as nick els and d im e s then and g rew larger later on. I never asked what the amounts were. But I can't get ter­ ribly ex e r c is e d about support for a m oderate leader. I don't know what this sudden morality is.” 

Brown gets agency post 

WASHINGTON (A P ) 
— President Carter a n ­ nounced Frid ay he will nominate Colorado state 
T r e a s u r e r S am u e l W. 
Brown Jr., who came to public p r o m in e n c e as a n tiw ar activist, to be director of ACTION, the volunteer service agency. 
2 South Texans take dairy titles 

Two South Texans won championships with their entries in the four junior dairy cattle shows Friday at J o e 
F r e e m a n C o­ liseum. 
Todd 
Knowlton, a mem ber of the Southwest 
Rough Riders of San An­ tonio. showed the junior champion in the Brown 
Swiss show. The c h a m ­ pion heifer i i i that show was entered by Rodney 
A lexander of S u lp h u r 
Springs. 
In tin* Jersey junior show the champion heifer was owned by Susan 
Cooper of Comfort. The c h a m p io n heife r w as entered by Jack ( 
Hall of Chireno. 
Ronnie Smith of G a r ­ land had the champion heifer in the G uersey show, with junior heifer honors going to the entry of K irsten Dig gin s of 
Mesquite. 

Leo 
Hoff 
J r . of 
Windthorst showed the champion heifer in the 
Holstein j u n i o r show, with junior heifer honors going to the en t ry of 
Jim m y Don Allen of Sul­ phur Springs.

Freeman Coliseum.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS -S aturday February 19 1977 

SATURDAY SIZZLERS 

Sunshine9 lakes go together 

Blanco 

It was such a wonderful day just to “ goof o ff/' 
The sun rose on a bright and cloud­ less sky. It was the sort of F ebruary day that has spoiled us for all these years in South Texas. 
Bonnie recalled som ething an aunt used to say a long tim e ago: 
“ This day is a credit to tim e." 
Being less philosophical about it — it was a day to loaf. 
Forget about getting a story. 
Let’s just pick a spot or two not too far away. L et’s drive leisurely, stop wherever the idea strikes us, picnic 

 and get back home before dark. 
We looked at th e m a p , saw the 
Highland Lakes above M arble Falls were less than IOO m iles away and headed in that direction. 
We went north on San P edro and then up U.S. 281. lf there is a highway leaving a city through prettier country than these ce d ar-co v ere d hills, we don’t know where it is. 
As we rolled along, th e re w as a big-eyed, brown doe peeping shyly out from the edge of the cedar thicket. And a little farther down the road, there was a flock of Spanish goats — spotted 

 or one of half a dozen colors —• scat­ tered in the trees of a rocky pasture. 
Against the gray, bare branches of the trees along a dry creek bed. there was a flash of scarlet berries. 
Bonnie thought they were haws 
Then cam e the G uadalupe — ru n ­ ning over the rocks — gurgling around the roots of the big cypress trees — its open pools sparkling in the sun. 
Soon rising over the dark green sea of the cedars and the little oaks were the twin brown peaks of the Sisters. We savored the memory of the day we spent in their shadows—at 
Twin Sisters, Kendalia and matchless 
Sisterdale. 

Texas has more acres of inland lakes than any other state. One of the largest and prettiest is the one behind Buchanan Dam. The lake is 3o miles long and about five miles wide —so large that it is a favorite of sea gulls. Here Ricky Stinnett, left, and Brian Perry, both of Round Rock, pause for a breather in the two-mile walk across the dam. an average cost of $9o,(1oo, duplexes and condominiums ll started with 1,5oo acres and now there are 5,ooo. There are nine tulles of lake front. More than $‘1o million has been tmested. 
Norman Hurd, president of the pro­ tect* has supervised tin' planting of more than 3oo,ooo trees anti shrubs — more than 18,ooo plantings around Hie golf course. 
The golf co u rse w as d esig n ed by 
Robert Trent Jones. Jones, long inter­ nationally known, has supervised th** construction of a golf course in Russia. 
And his son is supervising another iii the Kgyptian desert in the shadows of the P.v rainids. 
We bilked with Bill Lucy of the Hor­ 

 seshoe Bay staff. 
“ We have convention facilities for bill people and had m ore than 6,(1oo 
\ isitors last year," Lucy said “ We arc now booking an average of 2oo rooms a day. 
“ While our prime goal is us a ‘des­ tination* resort*' many people are building here, Outside investors spent 
$3 5 m illion las! y e a r W hile m o st buyers are from Texas, we have sold to people from the C anadian provinces of 
Alberta, British Columbia, Ontario and 
Quebec, from G erm any and Belgium and from Central and South Am erica." 
From Horseshoe Bay, we cut out lo 
Texas Hwy. 71 and then along FM 2233 

See H K .U L A N I), Cage IB 

The roadside park idea was born in Texas in 1933. But of the 1,1 OO built in the state since that first one near La Grange, none is more unusual than this one in the Highland Lakes country. It is on Texas Hwy. 29 just below Buchanan Dam. The entire park is a big granite outcropping, topped by granite boulders. Isn’t it a beauty! 
Blind man with an idea 

Marble Fulls' slogan is: 

“The city laid out by a blind m an.” 
The blind man who founded Marble 
Falls had a lug hand in early day ef­ forts to dam the Colorado River. These efforts led years later to the dam s and the Highland Lakes. 

The story is told by John Williams, editor of the Lower Colorado River 
Review, the LURA m agazine, in a recent issue. 

Adam R 
Johnson, a Kentuckian, moved to Texas as a young man. He 

 became a surveyor and a driver for the overland mail. 
Iii 1854 he crossed the Colorado on horseback at a shoals and was struck bv the idea this would be an ideal place for a dam. He took a piece of flint and marked the rocks there. 
Johnson enlisted in the Confederate arm y and rose to be a general iii 
Nathan Bedford F orrest’s cavalry. A battle wound cost him the sight of both eyes. 
He returned to the Marble Falls area and becam e a m ining and textile operator and businessman 

He did not forget the possibility of a dam on the Colorado at the site lie had chosen. Iii 1885 In* got the rights to build (he dam. lie even had sketches of the dam drawn 

But the dam was not built and John­ son later sold the rights. In time they became part of the Insull project and finally part of the Lower Colorado 
R iver A uthority dam -b u ild in g p ro ­ gram. 

And the giant Buchanan dam was built in 1937 on the site he had marked on the rocks in 1854. 

T hen c a m e the a p p e a lin g L ittle 
Blanco — and on up the road and off to our left the Blanco itself poured white over the dam in the little state park. 
In tim e cam e Johnson City —and crossing the Pedernales. Who could ever cross it and not think of LBJ and his great love for this river? 
On up the road and in time on the outskirts of Marble Falls and stopping at that roadside park high on the bluff. 
In the trees just below us a half do­ zen robins — stirred out of their winter listlessness by the su n ’s w arm th — fussed noisily. 
F a r below was long, narrow Lake 
Marble Falls and away off to the west the blue silhouette of another long Hill 
Country ridge. 
Beside the roadside park, a plaque noted the love another man had for this part of Texas. 
At the top were the words — “ THE 
HILLS HOME — and underneath this a few bars of music across the plaque’s face. Under this was the story: 
"M emorial to OSCAR J. FOX, com ­ poser of this song — 1879-1961. This is the view that gave him the inspiration for this beautiful song." 
We visited the pretty city park on the lake in the town of Marble Falls. Its m assive polished red granite benches and tables are of the same granite that was taken from this country so many years ago to build the Texas Capitol. 
We swung down to Max Starcke Dam that forms the lake and then took I’M 
2147 up the south shore of the lake. 
Soon we were at W irt/ Dam. behind which lies big Lake Lyndon B. John­ son. 
Magnet lf you don't believe water is a m ag­ net for people, you should visit the 
H orseshoe Bay developm ent on the shores of the lake. Bonnie and I turned in and drove about it. 
This was a ranch before the project started in 1971. Owned by a.family with major Coca Cola holdings, it was pri­ marily a hunting ranch 
Now there are 425 living units in the project — single family homes built at

BACON SIZZLER 

Pyndus announces candidacy 

By JIM WOOD 
Councilman Phil Pyn ­ dus made his re-election bid official Friday and took a slap at a major opponent, Councilman I). 
Ford Nielsen. 
The recent districting of council seats puts both 
Pyndus and Nielsen in 
District 8 and both are running. 
Using the mayor’s of­ fice at City Hall to make his announcement. Pyn ­ dus told a press confer­ ence he is a conservative and said his voting re­ cord reflects it. 
He accused Nielsen of 
Irving to distort that re- 
S.A. air program is asked 

Mayor Pro rem Henry 
Cisneros believes San 
Antonio ought to develop its own air quality objec­ tives before griping too much about current fe­ deral proposals. 
The 
E n viro n m en tal 
Protection Agency has proposed a “ trade off" policy for this region. 
Such a policy would require a reduction in air pollution to match an in­ crease that would come from a new plant or an expansion. 
The G reater San An­ tonio 
Cham ber of 
Comm erce asked City 
Council Thursday to pass a resolution objecting to the E P A proposal 
Council put off a de­ cision until it gets a briefing from the EPA . 
M eanwhile. Cisneros wrote the chamber board 
Friday urging it under­ take a study of objectives using various sectors such as industry, busi­ ness, schools and labor. 
Local initiative to de­ termine what San Anton­ io wants and needs is missing at present, Cis­ neros said. 

 cord and pass himself off as a fiscal conservative. 

Pyndus claim ed his> opponent is being fin-’ anced by

'Tonight’ to go live 

LOS A N G E L E S (A P ) 
— 
N B C ’s 
“ Tonight 
Sh o w ," broadcast live when it began in 1934, will resume the practice of live nightly telecasts starting M arch 15, the 
NBO Television network said Friday. 

The program, hosted by .Johnny Carson since 
Oct. I, 19H2. currently is taped each day at NBC’s studios in 
Burbank, 
C alif., from 5:3o to 7 p.m., for broadcast late at night. 

NBC said that on 
M arch 15 the program will begin at 8:3o p.m. 
PDT for live broadcast to most of the nation, alth­ ough the West Coast still will continue to get each night's show on tape at 
11:3o p.m. local time.

Raise for jail guards okayed 

 pjHmN&tWc 
• 3915 SAN NM O 
• CAU 736-1561 

A reclassification of 
Bexar 
County 
Ja il guards, providing a monthly raise ranging from $21 to $44. was ap­ proved Friday by Com­ missioners Court. 
County Ju d g e B la ir 
Beeves said the reclassi­ fication will bring all of the guards up to the ninth pay level for county em­ ployes. 
Some of the guards had been at the seventh level, he said. 

In cre a se 

Depending on the guard s’ current classificatio n . 
J udge 
Beeves said tho reclassi­ fication move will mean a m onthly salary in ­ crease between $21 and 
814 
There are currently 2o3 jail guards. 
Judge Beeves said he wanted to giv e the guards even higher reclassifica­ tion than what they received. 
“ But there is just so much money in the bud­ get and th at’s what I i-• mited us." he said. 
The judge also added the reclassification was part of Commissioners 
Court overall effort to upgrade the jail and its operation. 
Study 

A ja il m anagem ent study released last year strongly recommended higher wages for the guards 
In related action. Com­ missioners Court voted to 

 institute a new rule which would no longer allow attorneys to visit inmates iii the jail’s core area. 

“ The attorneys are go­ 

 ing to have to meet with their clients iii the same area where everybody else does, instead of the core area w Inch poses several security prob­ lems,’’ he said. 

W A SH IN G T O N (A P ) 
— President Carter, ap­ parently dismayed by the cost, has told the Pen ­ tagon in effect it should not buy any more 
$117-million emergency command post planes like the one he flew in last week. 
Administration sources said Frid a y C arter ex­ pressed his view in a brief memorandum sent to Defense Secretary Ha­ rold Brown. 
Carter flew to Plains, 
Ga., and back last week­ end in one of the jumbo planes, a flying war room from which he and key civilian and m ilitary leaders would direct the 
I S. response in event of a nuclear attack threa­ tening destruction of the capital. 
Enroute to Georgia last 
F rid a y, 
C arter was briefed iii detail by members of the military battle stall' who would iinin tin1 plane’s elabor­ ate communications and other equipment in a cri­ sis. 
The A ir Force now operates three National 
Em ergency 
Airborne 
Command Post planes and is fitting out a fourth with advanced gear, in­ cluding satellite com ­ munications terminals. 

I neiiiployinent is shrinking 

W A S H IN G T O N 
- 
Unemployment caused by natural gas shortages has shrunk to an esti­ mated 242,5oo after a break in the coldest winter in the nation's history. 
The Federal Energy 
Administration says the latest figures collected by the Com m erce De­ partm ent indicate shor­ tage-caused unem ploy­ ment has virtually ended in Maryland, Michigan and Wisconsin and has itnprovcd substantially 

 iii most other states. 
At the same time. In­ terior Secretarv Cecil 
Andrus, who ordered a 

 probe Thursday of off­ shore gas operations iii the Gulf of Mexico, an­ nounced a postponement of steps for new petro­ leum leasing off the P a ­ cific Coast 

Bus integration plan protested 

LO S 
A N G E L E S 
- 
Thousands of students iii the vast Los Angeles public school system boycotted classes iii an apparent protest against proposed busing for inte­ gration 
More than half the stu­ dents in tin’ predomi­ nantly white west 
San 
Fernando Valley staved away from school but other areas in the sprawling district were not greatly affected 
There is no set timeta­ ble for the busing, and, iii fact, no certainty there will be busing. The dis­ trict is under court order 

 to integrate schools.

Mideast chiefs 

W A SH IN G T O N 
- 
ITes'dent Carter says he is inviting leaders of the 
Middle East nations to meet with him ill W a ­ shington in preparation for possible reconvening of peace talks in Geneva later this year 
He called this year the brightest hope for peace he can rem em ber but said he could not guar­ antee success iii resolv­ ing the areas problems 

Talks put hack 

W ASHINGTON - The 
U.S. and Britain have re­ jected for the time be­ ing a South African bid for early’ three-nation talks on the Bhodesian crisis. Instead, U S. and 
British envoys will dis­ cuss tin* issue next week here. 

Reinstated guards to receive back pay 

Three 
County 
Ja il guards who were fired because they were charged with assault but later reinstated will be receiving a total $14,977 in back pay. 
Commissioners Court voted Friday to approve the back-pay allocation for 
Bobert Collins. 23; Charles Harris, 23. aud Jam es Lov mgs, 3o 
The court had earlier voted to rein­ state the men. 
The men will receive the pay they have accumulated since last 
May when they were indicted bv the Bexar 
County Grand Ju ry on charges of assaulting Pablo Garza, 33, of 1437 

Santa Barbara St., while he was a prisoner. 
Garza had been arrested during a disturbance at a service station and then booked in the jail where, he testified, the three guards beat and kicked him. 
However, County Court-at-Law Ray­ mond Wietzel found the three men not guilty of the assault charges after a two-day trial last September. 
The County Civil Service Commis­ sion recently recommended to Com­ m issioners Court the guards be reinstated with all back pay. 
Fired Heights teacher files suit over dismissal 

A form er 
Alam o 
Heights School District teacher filed suit Friday against the d istrict charging he was illegally dismissed. 
The suit filed by John 
S McDonnell alleges he was dismissed from his position as an 
English teacher at the Alam o 
Heights Ju n io r School illegally. 

The d is tric t’s school board voted to discharge 
M cDonnell at a Feb. 8 meeting even though the district’s superintendent failed to file his written recom m endation con­ cerning the matter, the suit states. 
The boaru also voted in secret not to pay McDon­ 

 nell tor w orking from 
Ja n . 24 to Feb. 8, a c ­ cording to the suit. 
The board actions, ac­ cording to the suit, vio­ lated McDonnell's rights. 
The teacher's suit asks for a d istrict judge to order the district to rein­ state McDonnell with his lull back pay.

‘ Diplomats an* just as es­ sential to starting a war as soldiers are for finishing it.” 
— Will Rogers 
In the same vein, bidding a slam is only half the battle 
There still remains the mat­ ter of making it 
Today's challenger gives us a neat ex­ ample 
Declarer was a bit disap­ pointed in finding such a heavy eonoenlralion in dum­ my's club holding He had hid the slam on the strength of the singleton club and • declarer would have much preferred to find more of dummy's high cards in the red suits. Nevertheless, the slam was a good one and needed only one of two finesses to work for success - at least a 75 per cent chance 
The club ace was won in dummy and the heart finesse went to West's king West ex­ ited with the club deuce and declarer was forced to ruff 
East's king Now the contract hinged on finding the dia­ mond queen After drawing a couple more trumps Irving lo decide which way to go, declarer go* impatient and decided to finesse* against 
H.im West took ih«* diamond queen and the slam was down on* 
Naturally, had declarer finessed diamonds against 
West, he would have made the slam Were there some clues that d eclarer had missed'* 
West's play of the club suit was very revealing He led a presumed fourth best and when next on lead, he ied the deuce 
Rarrmg some false cards, clearly this marked 
West with a five card club sui! 'don I expect all players to be quite aa accomodating in providing a count against the slam I 
This hit of information should have been enough 
After losing lo the trump king and ruffing the club king

SAN ANTO N IO EXPRESS — Saturday February 19 I 977 
H ighland lakes— good place to relax 

Continued trom Page IB 

 and 29oo to Kingsland. Kingsland is at the head of Lake LBJ. 
This is red granite country. The big outcroppings of red, given a bluish tinge by the whitish-green moss, were memorable. 
Rain, dark skies and cold of prev ious days had whetted our taste for su n ­ shine and the Texas outdoors. 
And this granite-jeweled country around Lake LBJ from Wirt/ Dam to 
K ingsland — with such sp e c ia ls as 
Sandy Creek with its wide, reddish- brown sandbars — made us forget the winter. 
From Kingsland we took I’M 2342 and then Park Road 4 to Inks Lake* 
State Park 
Inks Lake is the s m a lle s t of the 
Lower ('(dorado River Authority lakes. 
Bonnie and I think it is the prettiest. 
We picnicked looking out over the lake — the water shining dark blue all the wav down to the dam. Just across the lake from us was a particularly beautiful granite outcropping. 
The park features w ater sports, a nine-hole golf cou rse and 2oo cam p sites. The stretch of cold weather had cut the number of visitors the day we were there But it is one of the most popular state parks 
C h ild re n 

Several children were swinging and see-sawing — a man was working on his boat's motor — and a couple of families were lounging in chairs out­ side their motor homes, soaking up the sunshine. 
A man and a lively little boy were down by the lake and Bonnie wanted the boy for a picture. They were San 
A n ton ia n s — J e r r y T h o m a s and 
5-year-old Steve. 
“ When the sun cam e out, our family couldn't resist hopping into our mo* torhome and com ing up here." Tho­ mas said. 
From Inks we went north to Texas 
Hwy. 29. stopping for a few minutes at an unusual roadside park — a m assive g r a n ite ou tcro p p in g with b ou lders piled 29 feet high. Then across the up­ per ends of Inks Lake and to Buchanan 
Dam. 

 in this area but. time was running out on us and we did not drive out to them. 
A r e c e n t le t te r from M rs. L. R. 
Hereford Sr. of San Antonio heightened our appreciation of this area. 
Mrs. Hereford was born in Bluffton 
— not the present Bluffton but an ear­ lier one now covered by the lake. 
“ My grandfather Shaw was an early day Llano County sheriff,” Mrs. Here ford said . “ He w as a m erc h a n t in 
Llano but in the 189os traded his city property for a farm and ranch in the bend of the Colorado River. 
“ The town of Bluffton was nearby and my grandfather was postm aster there many years.” 
The largest island in Buchanan lake w as part of 
M rs, 
H e r e fo r d 's grandfather’s farm and is named Shaw 
Island for him. 
Bonnie and I are always amazed at how recent frontier days are in Texas. 
Though they had happened 3o years earlier, Mrs. Hereford recalls as a lit­ tle girl she stood on the porch of a little store at Bluffton and heard men “ tell tall tales” of Indian raids. 
Ironically one of the greatest busi­ ness failures of all time — the collapse of a utility em pire that had interna­ tional effects — had a connection with 

 the death of the little hamlet of Bluff­ ton far off the beaten path in Texas. 
Samuel Insult and his brother. Mar­ tin. decided to build a big waterpower plant on the Colorado. They selected the site of today’s Buchanan Dam — then c a lle d H am ilton D a m — and started work. 
When the crash cam e. Samuel Instill fled to Europe and work on the dam stopped. But the Instills had bought much of the land to be covered by the lake and many people had moved out. 
In time LG RA took over the project and completed Buchanan Dam in 1937. 
G ra v e s 

Before the land was flooded, graves in Bluffton and other cem eteries were mov ed about eight m iles west. 
“ Some of those graves had been iii the Bluffton cemetery as long as 8o to 
IOO years,” Mrs. Hereford said. 
We ended our “outbound” trip at the appealing little town of Tow. The view off to the east from that area is m ar­ velous.The lake is hidden but you know it’s out there. And that long ridge — another “ Blue Ridge” in the distance 
— is its eastern shore. 
What can beat a “ goof-off day” in 
Texas? . 

W hat s more fun than Dad and the boys fishing together? And where is there a more interesting place to fish than on the 
Colorado River in the shadow of giant Buchanan D am ? Joe Villa — his hometown was San Antonio — is now in the I st Cavalry 
Division at Fort Hood. With him are his sons, Zach, Joe and Scott. 

The dam is more than two m iles lote,'. the longest multiple-arch dam iii 
Hie I .S. There is a walkway across the dgiii with a m arvelou s view up the lake. 

Back iii San Antonio I telephoned the 
Lower Colorado River Authority and had the good fortune to talk with Art 
Anderson, parks and land supervisor 
He has been with the authority since 
1939 and k n ow s m uch of its even earlier history. 

I asked Anderson about the changes the lakes had brought to places such as 
Kingsland 

“ The Llano runs into the Colorado there.’’ Anderson said “ And vears ago. 

Kingsland w as a w ell-know n resort town with one of those old-fashioned, ram b lin g resort h o tels 
E x cu rsio n trains ran there from Austin. 
K in g sla n d 

“ Then that sort of thing died and 
Kingsland faded. At one time I don’t believe there were more than four or five people living there. Then the lakes came and Kingsland cam e to life.” 
The Texas Almanac now estim ates 
Kingsland^ population at 1,5o1). 
Anderson told m e many important things about the U R A developm ent but for this piece I was interested in his stories such as the one about a once-well-known Inks Lake institution. 
“ The Colorado River is the dividing 

 line between 
Llano and 
Burnet counties.” Anderson said. “ Years ago. 
Llano was wet and Burnet dry. An en­ terprising man anchored a houseboat 

 i i i Inks Lake just beyond the center line of the river so it would be in Llano 
County and started sellin g beer and liquor. 
“ It w as a busy place with people from Burnet County getting in a boat and going out to the houseboat. Som e­ times somebody would get a little too much beer and fall in the water. 
“ But they kept a hook handy to fish them out." 
The last lap of our trip took us up the west bank of Lake Buchanan — up FM 
281 to Bluffton and Tow. The LCRA has three small campgrounds on the lake
