Try a new taste o f Eastern food 

V ie tn a m e se food held no fas­ cination for m e at all until so­ m eone suggested I try it. 

The Viet-Nam R estaurant at 3244 
Broadway, specializing in crab cooked 
-even ways, cam e highly recom m end­ ed. 
Even so. I w as se cre tly relieved when the place was closed the first time I went there. 
What a pleasant s u rp rise —when I went hack and it was open — to find the food is delic ious’ 
The plainness of the outside of the building translates to neatness and cleanliness oil the inside Blue carpet and red curtains are cheerful and in­ viting 
Cue Nguyen, the charm ing lads who owns the restaurant and docs all the cooking, and her two sons (they wait tables) extend their own special kind of hospitality—m ak in g num erous trips from kitchen to dining room to lie sure you are enjoying your food 
And the night we w ere there, the restaurant took on a particular friend­ liness that I am told is typical of dining out iii Europe 
Custom ers were introducing th e m ­ selves from table to table comparing notes un the food and visiting with the proprietor. 
Two of the diners had visited the 
Vietnamese restaurant in Paris that I had read about — hut couldn’t quite 
Indies e vv as that good' 
Sprinkling 

Mrs Nguyen’s language is like her food—Vietnamese with a sprinkling of 
French and ” American.’* 
We tried crab cooked in three of the seven ways and thought each was ex­ cellent. 
The Crab Soup with Asparagus (ii Iii lor a cup) is made from a rich pork tunic broll) 
< rah Egg Rolls are longer, rounder and thinner than the Chinese variety and are served three to an order 
($2 •‘XII, already sliced for eating with chops! leks 
(Bv custom , ladies eat with red chopsticks and men with w hite') 
The egg rolls arrive al tile tuble nu y platter with bile sl/t d pieces ol lettuce 
The two al e eaten together vs itll the pa ante-lasting Bsh sauce 
Crab suprem e i i i liq is a mixture ut 
(Mirk, m ushroom s and bean threads and served with rice 
The other lour crab dishes include slut led crab. crab with fried rice ami mixed meal fried cl ah claws aud fried crab “ Ungers that are lightly salted and traditionally served with I leer. 

Where lo go 
What to eat 

Bv Jan e I Ibm h 

We ordered rose wine <55 cents per glass; also sold by the bottle) with our dinner. 
We also tried a chicken entree that is prepared with tiny slivers of hot pepper and finely-chopped lemon grass, a sorrel-type plant that has the arom a of fresh lemon 

Bite-sized pieces of white meat are sauteed iii a light and lemony sauce, and a plate of hotly-pickled Chinese cabbage is served on the side. 
For dessert, we tried both the flan cake and lychee fruit 
So many new taste experiences! 
Snow 

But equally interesting to us was meeting Sirs Nguyen, whose nickname is “ Snow." tin* nam e of her French restaurant iii Saigon. 
“ Snow’’ cam e here about two years ago us a refugee, selecting Sun Antonio 
I a r u use of the climate. 
She brought 9 of her 12 children and worked as a seam stress alter teaching herself to sew . 

Though Mrs Nguyen was successful, she decided to put lier 22 years ol b u sin e ss e x p e rie n c e to w ork and opened the restaurant three months ago 
Iii Saigon she had had three different restaurants, a building m aterials busi­ ness, a factory w here lacquer was applied to wooden objects and an ini- 
|M»rt business (after the French left. sin* bought fabrics and cosmetics iii 
( anthodia to sell in Vietnam). 
Now a citizen of the I S., “ Know" is enjoying her freedom. 
Mid s h e Ieels happy a n d s e c u r e iii 
San Antonio, One ol t h e t h in g s she t alk s at tout most is earning en o u g h money to put up a sign w e l c o m i n g V i e t n a m veterans

R. L. H a lle r o f Fort 
W o r t h a n d g r a n d ­ daughter. 

By E V E L Y N N SAW Y IK 
Mrs. Bobby Vinton came to 
San Antonio Friday to accept an award for her husband, singer, entertainer and film star, from the Polish Arts and Culture 
Foundation of San Antonio. 
The award was given to Bobby Vin­ ton and six others with 
Polish backgrounds at the Copernicus Ball in th e Hilton P a la c io del Rio F rid a y night. 
Bright and early Friday morning I met Mrs. Vinton for breakfast with 
Mrs. Charles Grace and Wanda Tome- zy k ow ska-G rabianow ska in the St. 
Anthony Madrid Room. 
The early hour didn't phase Mrs. 
Vinton, even though she had only a r­ rived a few hours before. She's used to getting lip at Ii:3o a.m. because of tin* co u p le’s five c h ild re n . Robbie. 12, 
Kristin, IO. Christopher. 9. Jennifer, ti. and Rebecca, 3. 

Playmates 

The couple has been m arried for 14 years after being childhood playmates iii Canonsburg. Pa., and attending the sam e Polish Catholic grade school. 
Mrs. Vinton was the only non-Pole at the school, but her parents wanted her to go there because it was Catholic. 
Three classes every day were con­ ducted entirely in Polish, reading, writing and speaking the language. All 

 and Mrs. Vinton laughed that “ for years I couldn’t think my prayers in 
English.” 
After Bobby g rad u a ted from Du- quense University in Pittsburgh and proposed a few family hurdles had to be overcome. “ His parents were a little apprehensive because I was Irish. 
“ When I met his grandparents, they discussed me in Polish without realiz­ ing I could understand every word they said. His grandfather was sweet. He kept saying, ‘But she looks Polish.’” 

Similar 

Mrs. Vinton credits their enduring marriage to their sim ilar backgrounds and knowing from childhood w hat 
Bobby wanted out of life. 
Their lifestyle has helped rather than weakened their m arriage. “ For Bob and me separation is very good. It’s extrem ely difficult to live with the same person seven days a week, 52 weeks a year. 
“ Ifs almost an impossibility. The way we live. I feel as though I’m on a constant honeymoon. When he is away on personal a p p e aran c es, I do the things I want to do —I paint, write, attend school activities and do volun­ teer work in several organizations. 
“ The day he comes home, my friends don t even call. They know I don’t do anything except what he wants to do. I devote all my en erg ies to what he wants. 
“ I overlook little annoying things. as I know he’s only going to be here for 

MRS. BOBBY VINTON 
...accepts husband’s aw ard 

 a few days. He does the sam e for me. 
We both work extremely hard to make each other happy. 
“ We have im plicit tru st in each other. You shouldn’t m a rry without this.” Mrs. Vinton smilingly recalls what one of their neighbors in Pacific 
P a lisad e s, Calif., said about th e ir healthy m arriag e. “ She said w e’re giving the neighborhood a bad nam e.” 
When Vinton’s work requires him to he away for long stretches of tim e 

—such as the seven months separation his TV show required —his wife joins him for long weekends w ith a couple of the children. 
At times, they all accompany him on tours, lf this interferes with school. 
Mrs. Milton feels, “ The education part of it is secondary to the family’s being together. During the slimmer we all tour together for six or seven weeks." 

B ackground 

Vinton has been a musical perform er since age 12 when he played in his father’s orchestra. Eventually, he had his own band, cut records and sang. 
The first two singing records he cut each sold over three and a half million, 
“ Ruses Are Red” and “ Mr. Lonely." 
During a slum p in his career, his mother suggested he sing something for the Polish people. All he knew in 
Polish was a Christm as carol, so lie wrote the lyrics in both English and 
Polish for “ Melody of Love” and it became No. I nationwide. 
The song gave restored pride to the 
Polish people, but it also gave ethnic pride to all nationalities. 
M rs. Vinton ta k e s e v e ry th in g in stride. A very dow n-to-earth brown- eyed blonde, she has learned how to m ake the best of life. “ H appiness makes the times that aren’t so happy, bearable.” 
Bobby Vinton is currently appearing in Las Vegas in the Riviera. Mrs. Vin­ ton is joining him this evening for a dinner party. 
McNay plans art programs 

McNay- Art In stitu te will p re s e n t two p r o ­ minent men in the art w orld in the next few days. 
Reginald Rowe, artist 
• and teacher, will be fea­ tu red w ith a la rg e exhibition of his most re­ cent work. The opening of 
Ins exhibit will be held from 2 to 4 p.m. Sunday. 
His art will rem ain on v lew through March 19. 
M itchell A. W ild er, d ire c to r of the Anion 
Carter Museum of Wes­ tern Art in Fort Worth. will give a slide presen­ tation and lecture ut 8 p.m. Tuesday. 
Wilder’s program on 
“ Having Your Own Mu­ 

 s e u m ” will cover 
Remington, Russell and 
T exas co llecto rs. Both events a re open to the public at no charge. 
R eg in ald 
Rowe is chairm an of the faculty of the San Antonio Art In­ stitute, a position he has held since 1964. In 195o lie lived in Cuba near Ernest 
Hemingway, the writer. 
In 
195o H em in g w a y wrote: “ Reggie Rowe is our neighbor in Cuba. 
You could not ask for a nicer neighbor nor for a boy vvho p a in ts h o tter every year. It is pleasant to look out the door in the m orning when you are working and see Reggie 

 in an old straw hat and navv shorts solving his p ro b lem s of light and shade and the different grays and greens that we both love."

FRANCINE A N D A N N IN TAILORED, SEPARATES 
...in peanut and flam e red from 4 Designer G roup’ 

MANNEQUIN MODELS, FASHIONS FROM SEARS; PHOTOS BY TARKY TARSIKES 
Peanuts color 

TRAFFIC-STOPPER SPORTSW EAR 
...Ann w ears w alking shorts, slicker 

By NANCY SCOTT JONES 
It ’s bound to happen when there’s a peanut farmer in the 
W hite House. 

And “ silo m iff,” it has! 
Tilt* fashion color for spring in the exclusive 
‘’(lath erin g 
D esigner 
Group” is peanut. 
But it's not tin* hard sh ell! variety. 
This peanut is refined — the shade ol freshly-toasted cashews. 
Clame red and accents of black and white are other colors in this group of learnable separates — blazers, tests, skirts, pants and dresses for day and evening. 
This week I was a one-woman au­ dience when Sears introduced the new edition of” (»athering D esigner” in private press showings in the St. 
Anthony Hotel. 
Presenting the show were Sears’ fa­ shion coordinator Peggy Vincent, exe­ cutive secretary Jackie Newman and 
Mannequin Models Ann and Krancine. 
’’Gathering 
Designer” is 
Sears’ group of couture-influenced coordin­ ates and accessories — jewelry, shoes, handbags, scarves and hats. 
Designed by a famous American fa­ shion house (not to be mentioned), the pieces in "Gathering Designer” are made to work together. 
It’s “ responsive wardrobing” for the versatile woman. See for yourself how the pieces can be tailored for a city appointment or casual for spectator sports. 
At top left. Fruita tie wears the fitted vest and slim-legged trousers in flame red. Her striped pongee shirt is the three color mix 
— red. peanut and white. She repeats the red and white pattern in a cotton scarf tied ill a wide band. 
\\ itll her is Ann in the peanut special 
— a man-tailored blazer and kick- pleated skirt in linen-like polyester. 
The black and white striped vest is a 

 fashion 

 sensational contrast to the soft-colored skirt and blazer. 
Prices for this high fashion are mo­ dest — Vest is $21; trousers are $23, and the striped shirt is $2H 
Ann's blazer is SJO and her skirt $21 
P in s trip e d vest is $19 and classic while shirt is $2o. 
‘‘Gathering Designer” also includes daytim e and evening dresses for 
Spring 77 
For day there’s the blouson dress in black and white or red and w hite pin­ stripes. The dress — trimmed with splashes of white at collar and cuffs and the self-tie drawstring belt — is a 
.perfect standby for unexpected ap­ pointments or luncheon dates. 
For evening there's a jersey tunic and skirt combo in flame red or jet. A matching turban adds that elegant touch of class. 
Fashions from ‘‘G ath erin g De­ signer” are in San Antonio Sea rs’ stores and will be available on a lim it­ ed basis in the catalog. 
The separates in this group are only part of Sears' spring fashion forecast. 
"G athering D esigner" represents the Fundamental part of a "Three F ” story put together by Sears’ fashion wizards. 
Fundamental means the classic good looks. 
But also newsworthy are the other two “ F s ” — functional and feminine. 
Included in the functional pieces are slickers, ponchos. Western boots, striped "T s ” and blouson jackets. 
Tennis shoes take on a new fashion dimension and so do crew socks rolled down to spotlight those slender ankles. 
The last " F ” is for long-lasting fe- minninity. Hats off to the French for making it important in all our spring design.

ANNOUNCES ADMISSION TESTS 

Students interested in applying to Saint 

Mary’s Hall for admission in the fall of 

1977, are invited to take admission 

 tests on the school’s campus, Saturday, 
March 5, beginning at 9 a.m. and end­ 

 ing at 
12:oo noon. 
Testing, which 

 measures student aptitude and 

 academic progress, is open to boys and girls— grades 2 through 7, and to girls 

 only— grades 
8 through 
12. 
Some 

 financial aid is available. 
Advance 

 registration would be appreciated. 

Elementary School 
655-3ooo 

High School 
655-7721 

Saint M ary's Hall does not discriminate on the basis of race, color or creed.

SA N A N T O N IO EXPRESS —Saturday February 19 1977 
Volunteers aid hospital 

By LO IS H AASE 

Neighbors and friends ask Jean Peacock, “ Why do you want to spend all that time as a volunteer at the State Hospital? Can’t you find something more interesting and rewarding?” 
Her direct answer is, “ NO 
Jean 's situation is different than many of the volunteers, but their answer to the question would be the same. All ot these volunteers will be honored this 
Tuesday evening. 
.lean is using her three full days a week of volunteer work as an experience building time with the goal of becoming a staff member at San Antonio 
State Hospital 
She has a master’s degree in social work from Worden s 
School of Social Services at Our 
Lady of the Lake University 
W hile working on her mas­ ter’s degree, she spent two se­ m esters on a p racticuni at 
SASH getting practical exper-* 

JE A N PEACOCK o nce and on-the-spot know­ ledge. 
Jean is married and says her husband. Charles, is as enth­ used about her am bitions as slit' is. 
Slie volunteers in the Crock­ ett geriatrics ward Her duties 

 include intake interviews, dis­ charge summaries and she also assists in teen treatment plans. 
You'll also find her helping with individual and group ther­ apy sessions, nursing home and veteran hospital placements and other areas. This has been her first volunteer experience. 
"U ni so happy in my volun­ teer work because I have a great compassion for the pa­ tien ts.” she says. “ And of course my long range goal of working full time here is im ­ portant. 
“ I have some very touching. good memories from my work 
Sometimes a patient finds me the one person he can relate to. If I can help with even a small improvement, it’s very rewarding.” 
Bad publicity and exaggerat­ ed tales of state hospitals frighten some potential volun­ teers. Jean says that with to­ day’s rehabilitation programs and medical advances there is no need to fear helping these people. 
Volunteers are extrem ely important to the total program and more are always needed. 

On Tuesday, at B:3o p.m. the 
Volunteer Council will hold its annual V olunteers Aw ards 
Night at Pecan Valley Country 
Club. 
Dr. Don E. Flinn. assistant chief of psychiatry at the Ve­ terans Administration Hospital and professor of psychiatry at 
UT Medical School, will ad­ dress an expected .‘IOO guests. 
Dinner is open to the public. 
Reservations must be made at. 
SASH 
Mrs 
Laurence 
J. 
Mitier, council president, will be mas­ ter of ceremonies. 
Dr. 
Robert 
M. 
In g lis, superintendent of SASH, will present special awards to Glenn 
Dennis and the Rev. David 
Moore. 
George o. B eeck ler w ill award gold pins, bars and cer­ tificates to volunteers and con­ tributing civic organizations. 

Porfirio Esparza will recog­ nize bourd members and vo­ lunteers from the hospital s lh climes in outlying areas. 
Jean Peacock will be among those receiving a Rill hour pin and she ll wear it with pride.

Keep peace in family 

D ear Ann Landers: 
Please settle an arg u ­ ment. I come from a large fam ily — aunts. uncles, cousins, ne­ phews. etc. — all resid­ ing in the area. 
At least once a month we receive an invitation in the mail to a gradua­ tion, christening, birth­ day, or what-have-vou. 
My husband feels they are a waste of time and refuses to attend any id these affairs. W h at's more, he won t let me send a gift. Only ii a function is for H IS . immediate family " ill he agree to attend. 
All I want is to keep peace .in the family. We have already missed the last two gatherings and 
I'm beginning to feel a chill 
What do von sav? 
- Mullet hear M ull: 
W hat do you mean your husband doesn’t “ allow you” lo attend or send a gift? Are you tn chains, woman .’ 
(in to tin* affairs if you want to — and let him stay home. 
A tin of home-made cookies or a chocolate cake makes a welcome gift if you can't afford to buy something.

Dear Ann Landers: 
Can you stand another letter on how to put out a grease fire in a frying pan? I hope so, because information of this kind can’t be repeated often enough. 
A LW A YS keep a canis­ ter or a box of baking soda by the stove labeled 
“ F ire .” 
A generous sprinkling of baking soda will extinguish the fire immediatelv. lf baking soda is not available, keep a large pan lid nearby. If a fire breaks out. clap the lid over the pan and remove it from the stove at once. 
It is difficult to keep a clear head w hen a grease fire breaks out. Flumes can be frightening. Since 

 my experience with the grease and the baking soda, inst seeing that red canister close at hand is a calming influence. Sign 
Me — Ex-Girl Scout 
Dear Girl: Thanks for the lucid instructions. 
You rate another merit badge, honey 
GUS. My informants say the large lid. to sm other the flames, is better than any­ thing. ) 
Is alcoholism ruining your life ? 
Know the danger signals and what to do. Read the booklet, 
“ Alcoholism — Hope and 
Help." by Ann Lauders. 
Fndose 5(1 cents in coin with your request and a long, stamped, self-ad­ dressed envelope to Ann 
Landers, care of The Ex­ press, Box 2171 San An­ tonio. Tex. 78297.

Express-Dtews 

Saturday February 19 1977 
Ayala fig h t 

The Mike Ayala-Romero An fly a North American Boxing 
Federation super bantamweight title bout scheduled for 
Monday has been postponed until Thursday. 

Promoter Tony Padilla said the decision was necessary because Ayala was slowed in training by a virus. 
"Mike had a little fever so his doctor said to lay off for a couple of days,” said Padilla. "That set Mike back in his workouts.” 
Anaya, form er world bantamweight champ, has been in San Antonio for several days training. 
All tickets already sold for Monday will be good for the Thursday light at Municipal Auditorium. 
Most fighters on the card are scheduled to workout at I p.m. Sunday at 
San Fernando Gym.

(AP) — (’ale Yarborough kept control d esp ite a constant pounding by a brakeless A.J. 
Foyt and won the 1oo-mile finale of the International Race of 
Champions series Friday, but 
Foyt took the overall title for the second year in a row. 

Foyt hounded Yarborough for sever­ al laps up to the finish, ram m ing the nose of his Cantaro into the re a r of 

✓ R E S ! U S , /Vig, t i t 

Y a rb o ro u g h 's m a ch in e at over 17o miles per hour. 
On the last lap, Foyt tried to make a move going into the third turn, after giving Yarborough one last unsettling 
"love tap .” But Yarborough anticipat­ ed Foyt’s move perfectly and cut him off. They crossed the finish line with 
Yarborough a car length in front. 
Bobby Unser was another car length behind, followed closely by R ichard 
P e tty , J o h n n y R u th e rfo rd . D avid 
Pearson and Al Holbert. Buddy Baker did not finish.

Bn JEFF GROSSM AN 
O f THI EXPRESS N EW S STAFF 
Jam es Silas concedes he will not return to his all-pro form this season. 
But, says the Spurs’ captain, he can still make a contribution. 

“ I can help out in certain a re a s ,” said Silas, “ like if someone gets hurt. or if they get in foul trouble. I know I can’t play a whole gam e yet, though. 
"I just want to get the season over with.” 
Silas made a second comeback from knee surgery Feb. ti against the New 
York Mucks. Since then lit' has play ed and practiced sparingly. 
“ T he k nee is g r a d u a lly g e ttin g better,” said Silas. "When I play on it, though, it gets stiff for about a day. 
Resting m akes it better. 
“ I can do a lot of the things I nor­ mally do, but just not as effectively as I used to be able to do them. I might be a second slower. 
"T he only problem is. everyone else is at their peak, they are where they

TUCSON, Ari/. — Stacy Bowman and Kerry Sterling of Trinity advanced to the third round of singles play in the University of nt Friday. 
A p a c h e s w in 

The Gonzales Apaches, with a mis­ erly defense, took a 68-39 victory over the Uvalde Coyotes Friday night to win the 13-AAA basketball title. 
Bobby Newton, of Gonzales, led all scorers in the game with 19 points, while Blake Underwood led the Coyotes with nine.

By K EV IN O K E E F F E 

Of TH* EXPRESS NEWS STAM 
Tarleton State defeated Trinity Friday night in a nail-biting, sit-on-the-edge- of-your-chair. don’t-go-out-i'or-a-eoke-yet women’s basketball game. 54-53, at the 
TI A A Tournament in Sams (enter Gym. 

Debbie Watkins sank one free throw with one second left to give the TexAnns the victory. 
The triumph for Tarleton puts the TexAnns in the tup spot in the two-day, double-elimination tourney. 
They whipped McMurry. 61-43, i i i Friday's open­ ing-round game. 
Trinity, with the defeat, will play Sui Ross at 9 a.m. Saturday. The winner will play Tarleton at noon for the championship. Trinity knocked off Sui 
Ross in an afternoon match Friday. 69-34. Sui Ross upset McMurry in overtime, 6o-56, to advance 
“ They (the TexAnns) are one-point better than we are tonight." Trinity Coach Libby .Johnson said after her club's narrow loss. “ It just means we have lo beat them two more times." 
Trinity grabbed an early lead against the pre­ tournament favorite. The Tigers jumped ahead 12-5 in the first 12:24 of the game. They did that despite some poor shooting and poor passing. 
Tarleton, which was led in scoring by Teresa 
Caruthers' IK points, pulled even, but a late bucket by Kathy Stidham put the Tigers ahead by two, 
25-23, at the intermission. 
“ We were trying to hit well from the outside," 
Johnson explained. "We wanted to hit well to try to bring their zone out. Then, we wanted to go inside. 
"They played a collapsing man-to-man and we had to adjust.” 
But Trimly fell victim to its own turno vers. 13 iii the second half and 26 for the game. 
The TexAnns, thanks largely to long-range shots from Caruthers, Watkins, who had 14 points, and 
Debbie Howard, who had IU points, outscored Trini­ ty, 9-o, in a four-minute stretch of the second period to take a 4o-33 advantage. 
But the Tigers, who played part of the second half without an ill Jill Harenberg, got 12 second-half points from Patti McBee to close the gap. 
McBee wound up with 17 and Harenberg, recovering from a fractured thumb and the flu. had 
12. Iii fact, two free throws by McBee knotted the game, 53-53, with ll seconds remaining. 

Bad times com e to Duane Thomas 

Unless he’s written a check in the last few days Duane Thomas has exactly $4.66 in the bank. That was made known in a Dallas bankruptcy court the other d a y . 
He also has interest in two vacant lots and his wife owns a small publishing company that doesn’t have any printing equipment. 
The biggie owned by Duane and his wife is the $2,ooo in equity in their Dallas home at 62o9 Lazy River. The home is valued at $2o,ooo, comfortable enough but rather humble diggings for a Super Bowl superstar of just six years ago. 

Several weeks ago Duane declared himself—and his wife—bankrupt and the other day his creditors were scheduled to assemble in court to squabble over the meager remains. 
None showed. All realized that there wasn't enough there to justify a two bit bus ride across town. 

Six years ago. when Thomas was 

 busy snubbing all of us reporters who gathered in New Orleans for Super 
Bowl VI, nobody could have convinced me that just a few years later I might feel strong sympathy for any financial stress that Duane might endure. 

How well I recall crowding into that sweltering room that was filled with hollers and happiness after the Cow­ boys strapped it on Miami 24-3. Tele­ vision lights blinded most areas and everyone who wasn’t poking a radio or tape recorder mike at some Dallas player was elbowing in other direc­ tions with pencils and pads. 
A mob of about 5o newsmen bud 
Duane backed into a corner and they were rewarded with nothing, absolute­ ly nothing. For the better part of five minutes I stood on the edge of that circle, waiting to hear a word—any word—from the lips of Dallas’ star running back. Then, suddenly, it struck me that I was just one of many reporters making bigger fools of our­ selves than Duane could possibly make of himself. 

After all, be d done his job. His work 

 for the afternoon was completed. Our chores of reporting still faced us and there we stood, crowding toward the one guy who had nothing to tell us. I moved over and interview ed Bob 
Hayes and then rushed hack to the pressbox and my typ ew riter. My thoughts, however, stayed with Tho­ mas. What a horse's tail he was. 

But now let's go back and look at the situation from the beginning, trying to keep un open mind. 

The bonus 

The key to the whole, sad situation seems to be the $25,ooo Thomas was given for first signing with the Cow­ boys. 

In case you've forgotten, or never did 

 know. Duane was the Cow boys* 

 number one draft pick in 197o. Ile probably could have been their 

 number three or lour pick just as ea­ sily because it s doubtful that anyone else held him in such high esteem. In short, he was a surprise pick, almost as big a surprise as Yale's Calvin Hill had been the previous year. 

The youngster from West Texas 
State signed a three-year contract with tile Cowboys that called for $18,ooo the first season. There were all sorts of 
"achievement" bonuses included and if he got them all—which he did—lie could wind up with an additional 
$1o,ooo for the first season 

Then. there was the matter of the 25 

 thou for signing. The lowboys ottered lo give it all to him in a lump sum or spread it onto his salary over a three- year period. Duane look the early lump. That, to my way ot thinking, was the major problem, the beginning ol 
Thomas' downfall. 5 ou see. when you count that initial stroke, the $25,ooo for signing, then add iii the achievement bonuses and then toss in the Super 
Bowl money, Thomas wound up mak­ ing about $8o,ooo tor his first season ol pro football. 

His trouble with the Cowboys i i i 

 particular and the world at large be­ gan the following July. 
Duane had used the "off-season" months to put some figures on paper and he decided that even though his second year contract called for $2o,oo(1. plus additional goodies, he had to wind up making less money. For one thing. he couldn't make rookie of the year and that title in his first season earned him about $2,ooo extra from the Cow­ boy s. 

Then there was the matter of that 

$25,ooo for signing. He wouldn't be getting that again. It was all gone. 
Since the Cowboys might not return lo the Super Bowl he also might not be getting the slice of that pie he received in his first year. The way Duane looked at it. after a great start he was going to make about $16,ooo less tor his second season. Ile asked to renegotiate his contract. 

Well. you remember the rest. He seemed to go pure bananas and never could get buck in the right groove. It wasn’t until this time last year that he snapped back and decided to rejoin the human race. But alas. he was a hair step slower, a fraction off in quickness, perhaps a year too late. 

He ll try again 

It s difficult to get huck i i i stride alter marching to your own drummer for years. But Duane tried. After more than four years of fussing with airline pilots, cursing coaches, fussing with ins teammates and snubbing even the reporters who wanted to help. Thomas became a willing worker and cooper­ ated with all. 

It was close, right down to the wire. 

 hut at the last moment he was cut by the Cowboys. So now he's busted and in the middle of bankruptcy hearings. lie s Kl miles or more from crowd s roar, stuck with one-sixth of two va­ cant lots and a printing company with no.printing equipment. 

No. he didn’t talk with reporters at his bankruptcy hearing. Not because lie w as snubbing them that time. He was just too embarrassed. 
Duane Thomas still runs each morning at SM I "s old Owuby stadium. 
'This coming season lie's going to try once more, try to get all the old juices flowing in the right direction and then hook on w ith some NFL team, any NFL team. I hope he makes it.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S —Saturday February 19 1977 

SPECIAl TO THE EXPRESS NEW S 

Trinity netters bag victories 
D a n C o o k 

Outdoors 

 w i t h l l a n K i o p p r r 

State offered part of island 

State Sen. A. R. Schwartz of 
Galveston says the General Ser­ vices Administration has of­ fered to split federally owned lands on Matagorda Island between Texas and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. 

Schwartz, who is the chairman of the 
Matagorda Island study committee, released a copy of a letter from Karl 
Merrill, regional administrator of OSA to Gov. Dolph Briscoe which says the 
Fish and Wildlife Service will receive 
15.716 acres toward the south end of the island, while the state will receive 
12.276 acres on the north end. 
The state portion includes the former air base and the various im­ provements, plus the Port O'Connor dock facility. The letter said the agency would be in touch with the stale later concerning the need for joint use of portions of the property at Port 
O'Connor and for ingress and egress roads. 

State Land Commissioner Bob Arm ­ strong said the acreage divided con­ sists of the “ high ground’’ of the is­ land, including the gulf beach and in­ terior tracts. It does not involve the 
16,37o acres of state-owned school 
Inlands on the bay side of the long, nar­ row. barrier island. 

The school lands, which include the bay marshes, are what the Fish and 
Wildlife Service want to control for the benefit of the whooping crane. 
Whoopers have utilized Hie marshes of Matagorda and St. Joseph's Islands as wintering grounds for decades, and several of the big birds have been us­ ing marshes other than those on the 
Aransas National W ildlife Refuge again this year. 
There is a possiliilits the state will lease a portion of the marshes to the service, but before any lease agree­ ment is reached, state officials should carefully examine — and make public 
— any restrictions the son ice wants to place on continued public use of and access to state-owned lands. 
Conference on screwworms 

Governor Briscoe will be the keynote speaker Thursday during a dav-long conference called “ Mission ‘77: Stamp 
Out Screwworms." 
The flesh-eating worms, which prey heavily on domestic livestock and wildlife animals, deer in particular, are in an uncomfortable situation at the moment, and conference planners hope to build up enough steam lo push the screwworm in the U.S. into obli­ vion.ink 
The screwworm had its back to the wall a few years ago. then fought back 

 to become as big a problem as ever in 
1976. But the cold fall and winter have helped. Tin* number of screwworm flies overwintering in this state should have been reduced drastically by the hard freezes. 

A new screwworm plant in Tuxtla 

Gutierrez, Mexico, was opened last 
July, and the production of sterile flies from this facility, coupled with the cold winter, hopefully w ill give re­ searchers the upper hand again. 

Tuxtla Gutierrez is located in Chia­ pas. not far from the Guatemala border on the narrow isthmus of the 
Mexican republic, which should make it much easier to eradicate flies to the north. 
Speakers at the conference will in­ clude Dr. Frank Mulhern, U.S. De­ partment of Agriculture; Dr. Ruben 
Fernandez Villalobos. Mexican Na­ tional Institute of Insemination; Dr. M. 
F. Meadows, Southwest Screwworm 
Eradication Program; Dr. ll. Q. Sib­ ley. Texas Animal Health Commission; 
Dr. Dan Pfannstiel, Texas Agricultural 
Extension Service; and 'I'. A. Kincaid, 
Southwest Animal Research Founda­ tion. 
The conference will begin at 9:3o a.rn. Thursday in Austin M unicipal 
Auditorium. 
Seminar starts Tuesday 

The Parks and W ildlife Depart­ ment’s special fishing seminar — an effort to increase sales of licenses — will get under way at 7:3o p.m. Tues­ day at Holmes High School. Loop 41(1 and Ingram Road. 
The free seminar will run two nights and will feature biologists and local anglers as speakers. The first two-hour segment will concentrate on where to fish in this area and the facilities on three lakes. Canyon. Calaveras and 
Braunig. 
Two films, “ Guadalupe Rainbows" and “ Fish for the Future.’’ will be shown the opening night. 

Wednesday night the audience will 

 have a choice of panel discussions to attend. Biologists, game wardens and local anglers w ill staff panels on saltwater fishing, stream fishing, lake fishing and improvements in fishing. 

The department’s seminar in Fort 
Worth drew a crowd of approximately 
RHI fishermen.

Tile Antonian High School wild game dinner will be held at 7 p.m. Feb. 26 in the Antonian gym. The stag dinner is sponsored each year by the Antonian 
Men s ( lull. 
Tickets are SHI and may be pur­ chased by contacting Buddy Kondoff at 
344-1882 or 342-7616.

Brawl 
UNIONDALE, N Y. (A P) — Fred Brown and Slick 
Watts paced Seattle to a 22-point lead late in the third quarter and the Supersonics held on for a fight-marred 93-88 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets Friday night. 
Watts topped the Sonics with 19 points and Brown added 17. Al Skinner had 19 for the Nets. 
New York’s Mel Davis and Seattle’s Dean 'Polson were ejected following a bench-clearing brawl with ll) minutes left. The scrap began under the Seattle basket with Davis throwing roundhouse punches that knocked 'Polson to the floor and cut ex-Net Boh 
Love alongside the left eye.

o o o, Wilkerson 5 O O IO. Johnson o 2 2 2, Tolson 1 2 4 4, O leynick o o o o,

SPECIM TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
SALISBURY, Md - Seventh-seeded 
Sandy Slap, of Trinity, shocked third- seeded Barbara .Jordan King, of Prus­ sia. Pa., Friday to win a quarterfinal match in the U. S. Tennis Association 
Amatuer Indoor Championships. 
Sta|) advanced to the semifinals with a 7-5, H-4 victory over King.

Burbank tumbles 

Second-ranked Houston stunned top-rated Burbank. 48-44, to win tho 31-AAAA second-half championship Friday night at Alamo Stadium Gym. 
Charles Bean scored 23 points and Abraham Davis 17 for the Cherokees. 
Burbank, which was playing without 6-11 Gilbert Salinas, was led by Leonard 
La miter! with 15. 
Judson captured the 29-AAAA title outright by slamming East Central. 91-54 while Jay won the 3H-AAAA second-half crown by defeating Marshall. 78-72.

 halted Incarnate Word. 47-39. 
St. Gerard's and Central will meet fur the fifth time this year in the AAA boys consolation. 
Friday night Nolan led Central all the way, including a top of 15 points with three minutes left in the third before the Buttons fought back behind four straight buckets by reserve center 
.Joe Petri and another by Bobby Do­ minguez that cut the gap to 41-36 
Several times in the fourth period 
Central came within six but that was it. 
In the game that followed. St. Ger­ ard's also trailed all tke way as Stroke 
Je su it’s inside strength was the difference. However. Chris Wehre's pokes from the corner helped the win­ ners build a peak 2o-point bulge. 
Healy-Murphy, ineligible last year after winning the Class AA boys’ title in both 1974 and 1975, broke away from stubborn Lubbock Christ the King in the last quarter for a 63-58 victory. 
The Trojans will meet defending state champion Galveston O’Connell at 
5:3o J).in. Saturday in what should be an interesting contrast of styles for a state championship game. O'Connell ripped Shiner St. Paul. 6o-44, in the other semifinal. 
In Class AAA girls’ play. defending champ Dallas Bishop Lynch blasted 
Houston St. Agnes. 6o-26, before Cor­ pus Christi Incarnate Word (champs from 1972-74) did the same to Provi­ dence. 7o-46. 
Two-time defending champion Ennis 
St. John’s will also be back in the fin­ als in AA girls after cracking Christ the King. 45-29 
The Crusaderettes will tangle with 
Shiner St. Paul, a 54-33 victor over 
Blessed Sacrament. 
Healy-Murphy trailed most of the first three quarters before finally tak­ ing the lead lur good ut 43-41 on a bas­ ket by Waymon Ezell with 57 seconds left in the third quarter. 
The Trojans stretched the lead to a high of nine points with 2:22 left in the game when Isaac Cain hit from the baseline to cap a string of five straight points that made it 6o-51.

 rebound with two seconds left 
George Irvin fired a long pass downcourt to James Cook for a fast break bucket, then made a trip shot himself midway through the stanza to give Healy-Murphy a pair of seven- point margins. 
“ We were kind of tight the first half from the excitement of being in the state tournament.” said Trojan Coach 
Charles “ Ik e” Harris. “ We were rushing our shots. 
“ In the second half, we got more mobility and started moving the bull. 
We started playing like we were sup­ posed to. When you play defense right, you can get the steals like we did. 
“ Their press bothered us,” he said of the Lubbock team's two-man traps of the man with the ball. “ We were ready for a 3-1-1 but they came out in a 
2-2-1. I knew they were tough but not that tough.” 
Two straight baskets by Bruce No- velli gave O’Connell a 46-46 margin late in the third stanza and the Buts went into their delay game to outscore 
St. Paul. 14-4. in the final round. 
Height made the difference in the two losing girls’ games for San Antonio teams. Incarnate Word scored 13 straight points to take a 19-6 lead and once led by as many as 25 over 
Proviedenee. An early run of 16 in a row by Shiner St. Paul gave it an in­ surmountable 16-6 lead over BSA, which got within five late in the third period 
Both defending girls’ champs looked very strong in starting their bids to repeat. St. John's broke out on top. 
16-o, while Bishop Lynch was ahead by 
22 at halftime.

Injury bug hits at Trinity again 

The injury bug has visited the Trin­ ity Tigers’ basketball team again. 
Reserve forward Jim Stokes suffered an ankle injury early in tlit1 first quarter of the Tigers' 1o3-H3 loss to 
Southwestern Wednesday. 
Stokes will not play in T rin ity ’s contest against Paul Quinn at 7:31) p.m. 
Saturday at Sams (’enter Gym. 

However, center Bob Hoebeke, the team ’s second-leading scorer who has been out a couple weeks with an eye injury, may be back in service. 
“ I hoping Hoebeke will be back,” said Pete Murphy, T rinity's coach. 
‘We’ve really had our share of bad luck since the season started. 
"Stokes is injured and now we have a measle epidemic going around cam ­ 

 pus That s all we need now is the m easles.” 
No less than four of Trinity's players have been sidelined at one tim e or another because of injuries this sea­ s o n 
"ll Hoebeke isn t ready for Paul 
Quinn. I guess w e’ll go with a couple of our junior varsity players. Dave Ash­ ton or Gibby Haynes.” 
Paul Quinn beat a H oebeke-less 
Trinity crew K9-87 on a last-second shot earlier this year. 
Darrell Williams and Danny Murphy will be starting at guard, the team 's leading scorer Danny Ivey will be at post, and Jeff Spillane vv iii start at the other forward spot. Bill Kilgore will assume Stokes’ responsibilities in tilt1 lineup.

A llergies develop polyps 

Dear Dr. Thostesnn: Iii a recent physical the physician — after what I thought was some considerable poking around — located a “very sm all" hernia in the groin. He said it was as yet too small to be concerned about.. Is surgery inevitable for every her­ nia. or is it possible to check or contain the enlargement? 
What recommendations do you have? I am 5o. and my occupation does not require much physical ex­ ertion — Mr. H H 
Surgery is not inevitable for every hernia, even though it may not be­ come smaller or disap­ pear. Nor will the hernia inevitably become larger. 
Your doctor can show you how to check its program by yourself. It involves putting a finger over the area and giving a slight cough. You may or may not feel the im­ pulse of the hernia if it is quite small. But you will if it becomes larger. 
Since your work is not strenuous, you will have to be even more careful about unaccustom ed heavy lifting The hernia should be checked by your doctor at least once a year. or if you detect a bulge. 
Allergies 
Dear Dr Thosteson: Send me your booklet on sinus trouble, and while you're at it tell me, please, how allergies are involved in nasal polyps. — .I VV. 
A person with a tendency to allergies develops nasal polyps more readily than does the non-allergic person The reason is that it takes very little irrita­ tion of nasal tissue to set the stage for growth of the polyps, and a mild allergy can do it. I have seen polyps develop into large clusters of tiny growths, rather like a bunch of grapes. One can usually tell whether the polyps are allergy-related by measuring the amount of eosinophils in the nasal mucus. It will be higher in allergic persons. Eosinophils are spe­ cial kinds of white blood cells that show up in certain staining material 
Dear Dr Thosteson: Can you tell me anything about the “blind loop syndrome” ? — H D. 
It is a disorder of the small intestine that results in 
.1 nutritional deficiency. It is not a common problem 
The term “ blind loop." while commonly used, is not entirely correct. The problem is a kind of stag­ nation in a portion of the small intestine caused by the presence of outpourings, as in diverticulosis. 
Or it may also result from intestinal surgery. Bac­ teria multiply in the area and compete for tiller own nutrition, particularly for vitamin B-12. A deficiency of B-12 in the follows. 
Other symptoms are diarrhea, abdominal pain and weight loss. 
Treatment includes injection of vitamin B-12. But surgery to correct the structural problem offers the only permanent cure. 

“ Yoo Can Stop Sings Troub le!" is the title o f D r Thosteson s booklet, explaining w hat sinus trouble really is and w hat can be 

 done abou* it. For a copy write to him in care o f this new spaper, enclosing a long, self-addressed, stam ped envelope and 3 5 cents 

 oar 
Health 
By George C. 
ThostesoivJH.D.

JEANE DIXON’S 
HOROSCOPE 

FUR SUNDAY 

A our Birthdav Sunday: 
Your entire year spar­ klet* with umpiring new improvements over the past. Some are surprises, others the product of hard work, seizing tran­ sient opportunity. This is simply a bridge to a more advanced way of life, not a perm anent phase. Accept the chal­ lenge: move up. R ela­ tionships change, not all last Today's natives are original thinkers, stir up debate. Those born this year will be philosophic, have the suavity of na­ tural diplomats, may be entertainers

Barking dogs 

Can you tell me if it is possible to file "disturbing tho peace” charges, or some such, against a neighbor because of a barking dog? 
The dog is con tim'd in my neighbors’ yard aud does not run loose. However, it picks the corner of their yard which is almost directly under our bedroom window as the place to do its I larking. 
That eorner is by my neighbors’ garage so they apparently don’t hear it. At least we have never sivu 
{anyone come out to investigate why the dog is barking. 
In addition to the barking, the dog has been trained to t>e quite vicious. I am even afraid to mow the lawn along the fence we share I once hired a boy to do that mowing and the dog jumped up on the fence and started clawing at him. 
I would hate to count the hours of sleep we lose because of that dog. but I cannot talk to my neighbors about it. 
When they moved in. they made it very clear that they wanted absolutely nothing to do with any of the neighbors We have tried to stay away as far as possible. 
Do we have any recourse in a situation like this-’ I don’t know that you can do anything, but I didn’t know where else to go for help. 
Sleepless neighbor 

\ spokesman from Ihe 
San Antonio Pollee De­ partment said the only legal action you could take would be to file a complaint in corporation court with the eomplainl elerk. 
C orporation eourt is on the first floor of the 
Police Department. 211 
YI. Nuevo St. 
The ease will he put on 

 the doeket at one of the municipal courts and both parties, the plaintiff and defendant, will he notified when they should come in and testify. 
Before you file a com­ plaint. yon have to know who the owner of the dog is. The pollee department has to have another party to serve the complaint on. 

N e w s e l l o u i 

Help! We live in t Ii*' Mort un-Son th west develop­ ment of Valley Forge, inst off O’Conner Road. 
Our elementary school children are bust'd « 9 miles (from my house) to Wilshire Elementary 
School. A new North East Independent School 
District school is going to be built 2.25 miles away in tin* Woodstone development. 
We have been told that it will be completed in 
August 1878. 
However, rumor has it that there will be enough children to fill the school without the Valley Forge children 
Could you find out what is really planned and tell me how I can find out for myself and other parents lust what is being planned for our children? . 
We are very happy with the teachers our children have al Wilshire. The principal is great and our bus driver (No. 12H) is super. 
But we would like our children to have a school closer to home. 
Mrs. K. II. P. 

Ed West, NEIS!) depu­ ty superintendent, said no boundaries had been established lur atten­ dance at the new ele ­ mentary school. 
“ We have bought the site. retained arehiteets and are drawing up the plans now.” West said 
“The school will open in September 1878.” 

“ I can ’t say at this time which subdivisions will be included In the school’s area. YVe won’t make boundary deter­ minations for a few months,” West said. lf you would like lo contact NEISH for addi­ tional information about the school, call them at 
Sii 42 Hi 

Dating service 

On Jan 8, I sent a local dating service $2o For this amount, I was supposed to have been invited to several parties and meet at least five |>cople. 
I waited until Feb 8 and nothing happened 
I wrote the man at tin* company lo complain about this 
Ile called me when he got my letter and started talking smart, so I just told hun I wanted my $2o hack and hung up 
I have not gotten my money hack yet. I can I afford to just give him 12o. 
Is there some way to make him return my money since he did not do wha! his ad said he would do? 
I am a widow and on a very small income. I think he should be made to return my money. 
M. V. 

A cheek for $2o has been mailed to you from the dating service. 
The manager said the ad did not say there would he any parties. The ad promises — guar­ antees — you will be sent five names over a six- month period. 
“It lakes a while to find compatible dates for the applicants.” the man­ ager said. “ She just didn't give us enough lime.” 
“ When we can get a country club built, we will have parties. Hut right now we just reier them to each other. We don’t conduct anything,” 

 he said. 
Ile said he was going to tell you be would refund your money when you hung up on him. so he decided to keep the $211 until the end of six months, as the contract specified. 
The service’s policy is to automatically refund 
Ihe $2# at the end ol six months if the applicant Is not given any names, 
Each name easts $4. lf less than five names are submitted to you, the ba­ lance el the $2$ will be returned. 
However, he will re­ turn your money lo you now. 

S h ellfish bill filed 

Al SHN (AP) - Rep 
Henry Alice, D-Houston, introduced a hill Friday that would hike the cri­ minal penalties for per­ sons convicted of selling shellfish taken from pol­ luted water. 

Alice s p r o p o s a l, prompted by reports that persons were taking ami selling OS stet s I rom poi 

 luted areas of Galveston 
Bay, would also allow those injured as a result 
’of polluted shellfish to sue for double damages, 
The maximum penalty for the crime presently is a I intl fine, but the mea­ sure would increase that to a maximum 
$1 tutti fine and a possible 
I Mil-day jail term, Alice 
Nod.

RELIGION 

T H E B I B L E 

No. 279. Joel 

The prophet Joel, son of Pethuel, described in vivid images the plague of locusts, and he encouraged the people to repent and to turn to fasting and prayer. 
“For a nation is come up upon my land, strong, and without number, whose teeth are the teeth of a lion, and he hath the cheek teeth of a great lion He hath laid my vine waste, and barked my fig tree: he hath made it clean bare, and cast it away, the branches thereof are made white ” (Joel 1:6-7) 
"Sanctify ye a fast, call a solemn assembly; gather the elders, and call the inhabitants of the land, into the house of the Lord your God, and cry unto the Lord Alas tor the day' for the day of the Lord is at hand, and as a destruction from the Almighty shall it come " (Joel 1:14-15)

The New Image Singers will present a concert at 7 p.m. Sunday at 
W aysid e Evangelical Free Church, 2918 Vance Jackson Road. 
Members of the singing group include, front, Steve Troxel; second row, Mike Bruce, Connie Troxel, Rosalee Buss, Joe Dean; standing, 
Steve Sternitzke, Ken Buss and Kim Bachman. The public is invited to attend the free concert.

Freedom: Gift of God 

One of the most con­ tro versial questions about freedom of religion in our day is the rela­ tionship between the de­ programming effort of parents and fam ilies toward people caught up in the various cults which have been made popular in recent years. 
The Moon cub. Hare- krishna cult and Children of God have been parti­ cular targets of the de­ programming efforts of parents deeply concerned about their children be­ ing brainwashed in some religious movement 
W hile the current controversy has erupted in California with the 
Freedom of Thought 
Foundation under the leadership of attorney 
M ichael Trauscht, the efforts to capture back the cultists have created kidnaping charges against some of the de­ programmers. 
The Foundation is us­ ing the laws on conser­ vatorship as a legal means of declaring the person involved incom­ petent and getting tem­ porary custody back for parents or family. 
Technique 
D eprogram m ing fo l­ lows a technique similar to the brainwashing itself with the subject kept away from all outside in­ fluences while the efforts are made to persuade them away from the cult. 
There's a great deal of emotional support for the deprogramming ef fort . 
The fact that many of tin* people who have been caught up by the cults have been underaged adolescents bas added a degree of indignation to parents who have felt their children snatched away from their families. 
The kind of techniques of indoctrination used by the cults also have creat­ ed a repugnance in the minds of people who are conscience of the p re­ cious quality of liberty in our land. 
Conference 
A national conference last week of religious li­ bertarians in San Diego. 
C alif., examined flu* problem from the stand­ point of people who are basically committed to evangelical Christianity but also deeply involved in the protection of the rights of freedom of conscience with it consti­ tutional guarantees of separation of church and f state. 
A group of deprogram­ mers confronted a group of llarekrishna devotees in the meeting. Emotion­ al tides were intense. 
One of the interesting idevclopments was that 

A k 

 m t * 

Bv 
Rev. _ nj 

W I 
J'J 
A 

Jimmy R. Allen 
Pastor, 
First Baptist Church 

 the two groups continued to dialogue following the meeting and found themselves finding some common grounds of con­ cern evolving. 
The courts are testing th«' conservatorship tech­ nique of legally justifying the arresting or kidnap­ ing of the persons who are being brought out for deprogramming. 
The presence of re li­ gious freedom is only as real as it exists for the most unpopular minority in society. 

The responsibility for maintaining that free­ dom alw ays lies in the hands of the sensitive majority. 
The right to win con­ verts and to indoctrinate them in a religious phi­ losophy so long as it does not undermine the order of a society is not only guaranteed by the con­ stitution but is a gift of 
God. 
When God refused to make a robot out of man. 
Ile allowed him the free­ dom to say yes or no to 
Him. In that way, the yes could be meaningful. 
It is important that we protect that freedom of conscience. 

The idea of depro­ gram m ing is a danger­ ous one. It can reach the point w here any religious philosophy that is unpo­ pular at the moment be­ comes a target for brain­ washing its converts. 
At the same time, there’ is a parental responsi­ 

 bility for minor children which is as deep as life, 
A parent has a re ­ sponsibility to protect that child until he reaches the age of legal adulthood. 
Where there is a minor child involved, the deprogramming effort is not a violation of an indi­ vidual and mature cons­ cience. 

H is parental respons- bilitv to make that kind ut judgment. 

W here the person is past the age of being a juvenile and has reached the point of adulthood chronologically, it is the responsibility of the so­ ciety to protect their freedom of choice even when their choices are unpopular. 
Freedom is a precious gift. It must bo guarded responsibly, lf it is lost for some, it is in danger of being lost for all.

McAllister, City Council­ man ( laude Black and

( ontraiding Co.

The Thrasher Brothers will appear in concert at 7:3o p.m. Friday at the Sam Houston High 
School Auditorium. Tickets for the concert can be purchased for $4 :and family tickets for $1o at Christian book stores. Tickets at the door will sell for $5. In 1975, the 
Thrasher Brothers introduced a song, “One 
Day At A Time,” which won the Dove Award at the G M A Convention in Nashville, Tenn.

San Antonio EXPRESS-N E W S --Saturday February 19 1977 

 i t t e M u s e u m s h o w s s t u d y i n k i t s c h 

[Review 

 v HOBERT TIEM ANN 

Th** Witte Museum is 
^ p lay in g an excellent didy in kitsch. 
TCitscil is art for the tu tees where the m asses lite** lit e r a te b u t a re iflfgDucated in art. It is lie art of fads and la- bialis. It can be turned 
•ut mechanically and has 
•cedule an integral part 
•fyotir society in a way 
I t a l high art could never 
I*. its purpose and func­ tion is to make money, not art. It is invading every aspect of our so­ ciety and affects each of its m em b ers. Its en o r­ mous profits are a source of te m p ta tio n to the avant-garde itself, and its m em bers have not al­ ways resisted this tem p­ tation. 

Since kitsch is the en­ em y of good ta s te . I w onder why o u r eyes have to be assaulted and our intelligence insulted by the Rodeo Show at the 
Witte Museum. 
The show originated at the Fort Worth Art Mu­ seum under the direction of R ichard K oshaleck. who has since been re­ placed. Six Texan and five New Y ork a rtis ts were invited to “ respond to" the Fort Worth Ro­ deo. 
The project was supported by the Texas 
Commission on the Arts and H um anitites. Since 
Texas spends less money on art than almost any other state, I wonder on what grounds this show 

 was selected for funding. 
The only good piece iii the Fort Worth show is not in San Antonio: Ro­ bert R aushenberg's Ro­ deo Palace is noticeably absent. 
Photos 
The best works at the 
Witte are photographs by 
Gary Winogrand. His ro­ deo and cowboy life pho­ tos are straig h tfo rw ard docum entations, without any of th e cu te n e ss or put-ons of the o th er 

 pieces. Since he is so ob­ viously out of place, I was surprised that he was se­ lected for the show. 
The biggest spectacle is Red G room s’s “ Ruck­ us Rodeo.” His outsized pinata-t.vpe s c u lp tu re s would be m o re a p p r o ­ priate on a float in the an n u a l P o te e t S tr a w ­ berry Festival and Rodeo p a ra d e th a n in an art m useum . Mimi Grooms does plexiglas equiva­ lents of her husband's work. 

Terry 
Allen and 
George 
Green. both 
Texas artists, have cre­ ated environmental pieces of sophomoric morality — bad country- western songs made vis­ ual. Ed Blackburn, the only painter in the show, exhibits a huge, o v erb ­ lown painting of a cow­ boy’s face that looks like a misunderstood copy of a Chuck Close painting. doe 
Z u c k e r ’s la rg e mural, made up of pieces of toilet tissue, only 

 serves to point out that there is a better use for tis su e p a p e r. 
A ndy 
M anti, a n o th e r 
New- 
Y orker, has m ounted a group of television sets on top of a corral fence that shows us sim u lta n ­ eous view s of p a ra d e s and rodeos. It made me aware of how boring TV is without the c o m m e r­ cials. 
Also missing from the exhibition is John Alber- t y ’s and Jo e F e r re ll 
H o b b s’s M obile R anch 

 piece, an arrangem ent of p ic k u p tr u c k s , h orse tr a ile r s , c a ttle g u a rd s and longhorn steers. This piece is so rely m is se d because at least it would have gotten us out of the m u s e u m and into th e fresh air. 
A c c o m p an y in g the show is a pretentious ca­ talog that tries to connect these works to the great tradition of realistic art in A m e ric a . T h e show will co n tin u e th ro u g h 
April J. 

RODEO SH O W at W itte include 
“W aitin’ Behind the Bullpen” by Mimi 
Gross Grooms.

Friday there is nothing lie would like m o r^ th an a re m a tc h with M ayor

Bill Blackburn.

John Igo, professor at 
San Antonio C ollege, will p resen t a program on copyright information for artists at 7:3o p.m . Mon­ day at th e S o u th w e st 

('raft Center. 

The presentation w ill co v er th e c o p y r ig h t s available for handicrafts] and other works of art.

Come hear the mellow pop sounds of the New 
Christy Minstrels. The world famous group combines the best of the contemporary and pop sounds to create a unique new music of their own. Come early and enjoy a delicious buffet from 5:3o to 8:oo. Showtime’s at 8:45 with dancing before and after the show. Admission for the show is Just $6 per person. See for yourself why “The Best Country Club in Town” is becoming “The Home of the Big Stars”

Great America’s 

 daring designs 

 make difference 

What m akes the really great homes in San Antonio 
Great America homes? It’s quality built hom es with exciting design features that say personality. 
They are the homes that su r­ pass excellence to combine the u n ex p e cte d with tru e q u ality and elicit “ oohs and aahs” from prospect ive homebuyers. 
Soaring vaulted ceilings 
These tine fe a tu re s include soaring vaulted ceilings that so­ m e t im e s ex te n d beyond second-story living areas; b a l­ conies that overlook beautiful views outdoors aud o v e rh a n g spacious living a re a s indoors; and w o o d b u rn in g fir e p la c e s with highly creative and unusual brick treatm en t. All cause ex­ citement among visitors. 
Overhead skylights open up unexpected areas; multi-levels distinguish rooms without r e s ­ tricting space: and glass panels and a tr iu m s add d r a m a tic d i­ m en sio n s to living a r e a s by bringing home and environment together as one. 

Seven sites of prestige for locales 

Every room is detailed with careful attention to quality, de­ sign styling, p rac tic a lity and energy-efficiency. But all have a pizazz of their own, whether in­ side or out. 
Because every Great America hom e is d esig n for its own homesite, no two or alike. Cus­ tom finishing and design options let your G re a t A m erica home reflect even more of your p e r­ sonality and lifestyle. 
You will find Great America homes in San Antonio’s finest com m unities. In northw estern 
San Antonio, visit Park Forest, north on Huebner Road off NAV. 
Loop 41o, where hom es ran g e from $59,IKK) to $1oo,ooo. Hidden 
Creek features Great A m erica

NAV. Loop 41o.

Wurzbaeh Road off NAV. IM IO.

Va nee .Jackson and W urzbaeh 
Roads and features new homes from $75,ooo to $11o,ooo.

AFB 
AFB, 

Value brightens picture 

 s p e c ia l t o t h e g o l d e n t w i n s 
CHICAGO - With inflation taking a heavy toll on every fam ily’s budget, many ho­ meowners have discovered the current value of their property is the brightest spot on their financial picture. 
‘‘Since IHM, while the cost of living has increased 82.7 per cent, the aver­ age selling price of most homes has climbed well over IOO per cent,” re­ ported Ray Bax ter of Baxter and 
Swinford. Realtors, in Houston. 
'Cushion of profit' 

Baxter is also president of RI:',LO. the nation's largest not-for-profit relo­ cation service. “ For m any families, home ownership has prov ided a cu­ shion of real profit that meets the challenges of recent inflation.” 

But. if you’re planning to sell your home in the near future, pricing can be difficult. " I t ’s as easy to underesti­ mate a home’s market value as it is to overestim ate its potential selling price. That impressive IOO per cent, 
1o-year figure is a national average that may or may not reflect local market conditions,” Baxter cautioned. 
“ To determ ine a fair and realistic selling price, a home seller can benefit from the advice of a professional real estate broker in his or her own community.” 
“ A lot of things other than market appreciation can affect a hom e’s selling price.” Baxter said. “ Home improvements, for instance, can either add or detract from selling appeal, depending on how they’re handled.” 

R F LO. which has more than 9oo members serving 9,ooo communities nationwide, has a few home improve­ 

 ment tips for homeowners concerned with their home’s potential resale: 
• Keep the home in tip-top repair. 
Repaint when needed, replace garage doors, shutters, wooden steps. While these kinds of improvements may add little to a home’s selling price, left undone, they put a home in the real estate market’s bargain basement. 

•Make improvements certain to ap­ peal to potential buyers. Modernize kitchens and bathrooms; add a first floor powder room. 

• Make home improvements in line with other homes in the neighborhood. 
If your house has two bedrooms and all your neighbors have three or four, a room addition is likely to increase your home’s resale value. 
•Scrap ideas for a basement recrea­ tion room. Few buyers today want to spend much time underground. 
•Consider a ground level fam ily 

 room and patio. Both are high demand items among shoppers for home today. 

•Don’t let your home improvements out price other houses in your neigh­ borhood. The most important factors in determ ining any home’s market value are the homes nearby. Sw im ­ ming pools and tennis courts seldom fit into com m unities dominated by 
$3o,ooo bungalows. 

•Before going ahead with your home improvement plans, ask a reputable real estate broker for his opinion. He’ll be able to give you a pretty good esti­ mate of just how much the improve­ ment can add to your home’s selling price. 

“ Sometimes, a fam ily’s needs and wants outdistance their present home and neighborhood." notes Baxter. 

It’s a good moving. idea, then, to consider 

Oakcreek Northwest, one mile north of N.W. Loop 41o via Vance 
Jackson Road, will present another Mike Kinder original this weekend. At 1o9o2 Wild Grape in the master craftsman's showcase community is a striking, daringly different four-bedroom, four-bath masterpiece with two patios, family room, game room, bar area, dining room, all-electric kitchen with breakfast bar and a two-car garage, finished to the point of paneling. The custom builder’s homes in this area are priced from $79,5oo.

Close door 
Homeowners with elec­ tric baseboard arc trying to reduce their bills by drastically reducing the tem perature in some rooms when they are not being used, reports the 
Better Heating-Cooling 
Council. 
If the doors to those rooms are kept open, they defeat their purpose because the heat from the other rooms flows in­ to the cool areas, so the units in the warm rooms keep working overtime as tile heat flows out.

EE Ray Ellison Homes 

Country living turns 
Tanglewood lifestyle 

This weekend many families will drive through beautiful wooded countryside to visit Ray 
Ellison's Tanglewood, where country living is transformed from a weekend excursion to a daily lifestyle in the desirable northwestern quadrant of San 
Antonio. 
Located within easy driving distance or the neighboring UTSA campus, the im posing t ’SAA com plex and the splendid medical facilities of the South 
Texas Medical Center, Tanglewood is at the heart of the dynamic movement m arkin g San Antonio's th ru sting growth northwest. 

CLA S£lH *D D ISPLAY 
CLASSIFIED ' m S P D o T 

At the same time, Tanglewood offers the peaceful serenity of carefree country living amid gracious oaks and rolling landscapes. 
Innovative, contemporary designs by 
Hay 
E llison arch itects m ake 
Tanglewood an interesting combina­ tion of three- and four-bedroom, one- and two-story homes beginning in the low $4l)s, available with VA, FUA and conventional financing. 
Fireplaces featured in most plans bring crackling warm th and rustic glamor to crisp Tanglewood evenings. 
But the rustic charm is mixed with contemporary convenience in beauti­ ful. functional kitchens that transform cooking chores into cu linary adventures. Rich, handcrafted wood cabinetry; self-cleaning, double-oven 

 electric ranges; dishwashers and dis­ posal units; plus stainless steel sinks and fixtures all combine to allow kit­ chen chores to be performed with more fun and less fatigue. 
Although the benefits of Tanglewood livin g are m any and varied for housewives and mothers, children and teenagers from the wooded subdivision enjoy outstanding educational fa c i­ lities of the Northside School District, providing in te restin g and diverse social programs and extracurricular activities for young people of all ages . 

For weekend or evening recreation iii the great Tanglewood outdoors, tennis courts and swimming pool arc nearby. For those whose en tertain ­ ment tastes lean to the night life, dis- 

Ray Ellison's T an glew ood offers beautiful homes in exqu isxtely landscaped settings in the g row ing northw estern q ua d ra n t o f the city, with easy a c­ cess to m ajor arteries and expressw ays. 

 colhcque dancing and undine cuisine abound in exciting northwestern San 
Antonio, with the most popular spots located only m inutes away via ex-

 presswavs,

Ellison representatives art' ready to

CLASSIFIED D ISPLAY 

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL REPORTED RECENTLY THAT “THERE IS GOING TO BE A HOUSING BOOM IN 
1977 . . . BUT THE BOOM WILL BE GOOD NEWS ONLY FOR THE RELATIVELY AFFLUENT BUYER. THE 
PREDICTED SHARPLY HIGHER PRICES OF NEW HOMES THIS YEAR INDICATE THAT MOST BUILDERS APPEAR 
TO BE WRITING OFF LOW-INCOME AND FIRST-TIME BUYERS ” PARADE’S LLOYD SHEARER WROTE: “ THE 
AMERICAN DREAM OF OWNING A HOME IS RAPIDLY GROWING FAINT . . ” THERE S NO SHORTAGE OF 
GLOOM AND DOOM PREDICTIONS. 
Pessimistic forecasts are based on rising costs of land and lumber, increased labor costs and higher interest rates that keep edging upwards, along with escalating energy costs. 
BUT SAN ANTONIANS OF MODERATE INCOME ARE BUYING. 

THEY’RE INVESTING IN RAY ELLISON HOMES AT ROUGHLY DOUBLE LAST YEAR’S RATE, DESPITE THE 
GLOOM AND DOOM FORECASTS. THEY KNOW SOMETHING THE GLOOM AND DOOMERS DON’T REALIZE. 
RAY ELLISON S REPUTATION IS LARGELY RESPONSIBLE FOR BUYER-CONFIDENCE. 

San Antonians know that Ray Ellison isn’t “writing off low-income and first time buyers,” and that he isn’t preoccupied solely with the “ affluent buyer." 

RAY ELLISON HAS MASTERED THE ART OF VOLUME BUILDING. 

San Antonians know that over the years Ray Ellison has built a management team that knows how to apply the very latest in construction techniques and methodology, from design through slab and final. People know that the 
Ellison team takes full advantage of volume purchasing strategies applied to building materials and supplies; they know, too, that the Ellison financial management team can achieve the most favorable interest rates and terms available for the home buyer. They know that Ellison Customer Service is a commitment in good faith. Also, the word is out that the Ray Ellison energy package is a real energy saver, and not a piece of “ fluff” merchandising. 

A WORD OF CAUTION. 

THE MOST CAPABLE FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT IN THE WORLD WILL NOT STOP THE ECONOMIC PRESSURES 
DRIVING UP THE PRICES OF NEW HOMES TODAY. WHATEVER OUR EFFORTS, INTEREST RATES WILL RISE 
IN THE LONG RUN. EVEN THE MOST EFFICIENT ENERGY PACKAGE AVAILABLE WON’T HOLD BACK RATE 
INCREASES APPLIED TO SCARCE ENERGY RESOURCES. ALSO REST ASSURED THAT COSTS OF LUMBER AND 
OTHER BUILDING MATERIALS ARE NOT COMING DOWN. 
NOW MAY BE THE VERY BEST TIME FOR BUYING YOUR NEW HOME. 

It’s a decision that only you can make. But when you take a first hand look at the Ellison homes being built today, you will see that Ray Ellison understands the economic situation and is doing something about it, in terms of quality and economy. 

RAY ELLISON UNDERSTANDS THE BOTTOM LINE. 

SO DO THE SAN ANTONIANS WHO ARE BUYING RAY ELLISON HOMES. THAT’S WHY THEY’RE BUYING, 
AND WHY THEY WON T WAIT FOR ANOTHER GREAT YEAR. THEY KNOW THE TIME TO MAKE THEIR MOVE 
IS NOW, BEFORE THE POINT IS REACHED WHERE DEMAND EXCEEDS SUPPLY. 

SAN ANTONIANS KNOW THIS IS THE YEAR THEY WERE WAITING FOR LAST YEAR!

SAN AN TO N IO EXPRESS —Saturday February 19 1977 
Homes by M orton/S .W . score huge S.A. success 

Two different housing series by Morton / Southwest clearly tell how the building - develop­ ing firm became the favorite among San Antonians last year. 
Featured among three neighbor­ hoods, each series reveals that Morton 
/ Southwest does offer more home for the money. 
Freedom, Success 
The two series are aptly named, too. 
Freedom Homes are called that be­ cause they, literally, set buyers “ free from re n t" into a new world of ho­ me ownership. Success Homes are so named for the series* unique features that would make the purchase of any a sure success. 
"A ffo rd a b ility " is a key word for each series.

Pantry kitchens feature the rignt kind of appliances to lessen the work­ load for today’s hom em aker. D ish­ washer, disposers, ranges, vent hoods and abundant cabinetry are provided in Freedom Homes. A ll appliances carry the reliable Magic Chef brand name.

The reason'.' Solar energy which, according lo Harold B 
Olin. can be as effective a source of home energy iii northern cities such as 
Mew York and Philadelphia as iii sun belt cities such as Albuquerque and 
Tucson 
Meet needs

Housing and I lium Developm ent is stepping up the amount of research grants on solar projects olm is director of architectural and construction research lot the Toited 
Slates Teague of Savings Associations.

Part of the reason. Olin said. is that 
H T D is "p r im in g the solar pum p” with grant money authorized by the 
Solar Healing and Tooling Demonstra­ tion Act. Last year. H TD spent 84 m il­ lion tn encourage construction of near­ ly I ..■jim solar homes 

Olin estimated that tin' H TD grunts account for approximately half of the solar homes being built 
Savings associations also are financ­ ing an increasing number of solar en­ ergy hom es, O lin said. 
P e rh a p s surprisingly , several of the solar-or­ iented associations uro in northern, cold-weather states

"solar furnace” which combines both heat collection aud heat storage* tune!ions

It’s better. 
This large develop­ ment, by Don Smith Co., is located 15 minutes northwest of San Antonio in what has to be described us some of the most beautiful land in tin* 
Hill Country. 
Thousands of acres of rolling hills and valleys, spanning Kendall, Comal and Bexar Counties, fea­ ture 2Vfc- to 18-acre tracts that provide secluded homesites among the nu­ merous trees. Spectacu­ lar views are possible from the many hilltop trees 
Amenities 
Buyers in Fair Oaks will find an abundance of opportunities for hiking, biking and horseback riding along trails. And, there’s exciting news for the tennis buffs: eight new courts are completed at the Fair Oaks Racquet and Swim Club 

The ru s tic settin g of 
F a ir O aks, part of the historic old F a ir Ranch, will suit modern families with the conveniences of city-type utilities.

Fair Oaks is reached most easily by driving north on N.W. Ill IO. Exit at Leon Springs, then proceed north on the ac­ cess road to the Camp

FAIR OAKS . . . sprawling meadows, surging hilltops with views for miles, native grasses and gnarled oaks . . . as close as possible to the way Mother Nature intended it to be. 
Fair Oaks was once a historic ranch, but now welcomes you to its acres of country living. 

Th to 15 acre tracts, most with central water systems, offer buyers choice sites in Bexar, 
Kendall and Comal Counties, riding trails for horses, paved roads and the finest of recreational facilities at the Fair Oaks 
Racquet and Swim Cluh. 

Elegant homes, built by the Don Smith Company, are already available for viewing. Located just 16 miles north of 
Wonderland near IH IO, Fair Oaks is ideal country living . . . not far from the city.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS —Saturday February 19 1977 
Care of lawn follows rules 

Bv TERRY WILBOl UN 
COUNTY EXTENSION HORTICULTURIST ll your lawn is lo be neat and attractive, you must mow it re­ gularly during the growing sea­ son. The mow ing height and how often you mow depends on type of grass, number and kind of weeds, fertilization and rainfall. 
The kind of mower is important. The reel mower leaves a more desirable eat than the rotary mower. The reel mower requires more maintenance, but it will not damage the leal tips as badly as the rotary mower. Peel mowers are more expensive than ro­ tary types and are not as available on the market. Whatever tv pc of mower von use. a sharp blade* is essential for healthy, good-looking grass. 
Mowing home lawns 
• As soon as newly planted grass reaches the desired height, begin mow mg. 
•Coarsc-textured grass needs a mow higher than fine-textured 
•Shaded areas need mowing height raised about U inch higher than nor­ mal 
• Mow often en auh that nm never remove more than 2 * of leaf area at one time 
To properlv cart* tor vour lawn. keep vuur mower sharpened and in coml working condition s *t \>*ur mower at the correct height for m ur tv pc of grass. For safotv keep your lawn free of all trash and debris 
Recommended heights of eul are 

 rate of five* pounds per I.(MHI sq. It. of area. Sweep off any spilled material from walks or drives to avoid an iron stain. 
Other iron amendments may he used, such as sulfa soil or chelated iron. The use* of soil sui or sulfur soil is helpful iii releasing iron iii alkaline soils Elemental sulfur mav b e u n ix ! once or twice a year at the rate of 1o-2o pounds per 1.ooo sq ft. in lieu of. or in addition to. iron sulfate if iron chloro­ sis is a chronic problem 
Follow the Spring iron application during the same period w eb .. balanced fertilizer program using nitrogen i\ i. phosphorus ii' 
.

Thatch is the undecomposed laver of crass and grass residue that builds up on the si ii I surface iii lawns 
This thatch layer is usually more severe in 
• ■Id sods Some thatch is good for the grass, but often diseases aud inserts build up i ii the laver. An old lawn may have ;i thatch laver so deep that most ut tin* grass roots have difficulty crow mc to the soil 
The most accepted way to dethatch a home lawn is bv vertical mowing. 'Flu* vertical mower is a specialized ma­ chine that thins the grass and brings much of the thatch to tin* surface of the grass 
You then sweep, rake or vacuum tins material from tin* lawn 
Most of our lawns need dethatehiug every two or th ret* years if you use high fertilization rates. Early Spring is the ideal lime lo dethatch, lint you ran use the vertical mower anytime during the growing season without severely damaging the turf 
You should not vertical mow during the late Fall and Winter, Most rental establishments have vertical mowers available on an hourly rental basis. 
Apply ferrous sulfate during the 
March 1-15 period to a dry lawn at the 

 potash (K l nitrogen she 
Vugustnic turf year. lf the so matter, less .»< needed 
N P K several ways 
Following are 
• Per! I ll/» d . i’’- 5 
|H*riod wuh a 15 5 5 I or similar formula at 
25 pounds per I non sq 
•Fertil >v d ire . 
‘ « iud w it h am monium pounds per I (MMI sq application during the duly 1-15 jM-riod lf the lawn shows sigils of iron defi­ ciency (yellowing), repeat the March recommendation or iron or sulfur supplements 
•Fertilize during the Oct 15 - Nov I 
I wried with a ti IO 4, 5 IO 5. S 12 4 or sim ilar forum ula at the rate of 2o pounds per 11M ll I sq ft 
•Avoid adding nitrogen during the late Sn. inter - early Fall period This practice will, it is believed, reduce disease and insect problems 
After each of the iron and fertilizer applications, water the equivalent of one or two inches of rainfall. 
Adding water to turf is nccesoary only when the soil has been depleted of available w a t e r and lawn grass ap­ proaches the wilting range 
During the October-March period, i ii the absence of rain, turf should be wa­ tered every two to three weeks, the equivalent id one to two inches of rainfall each application. During the 
\pril-September period, when rainfall is not equivalent lo one or two inches, supplem ental waterings is needed every one to two weeks. During 
Springs of normal rainfall, watering is often not needed until .lune, 
Light daily sprinkling cncoumugcs a shallow root system which results iii a weak plant. Less frequent, deep wa­ tering recharges the soil and promotes a deep root system and a more vigor­ ous turf. lf you are interested iii learning more about lawn care, be sure to at­ tend tin* Stroud session of the Spring 
Hardening Schools, Dr Richard Tublc. turf specialist from Texat* A \ M I 111- versity, will lie the featured speaker 

The programs will lie held Monday, 
Feb. 21 at 1:3(1 p.in at the San Antonio 
Harden Center. 331o N New Braunfels

I have lived in San Antonio for about a year and have added gypsum to my garden to loosen the soil. 
Should I add it every year? lf s o , will it hurt the soil? 

Applying gypsum 

 every two or three years is probably best. It will not damage the soil, though lf the tilth of the 

 soil is not improved after applying the first year, I would reapply the next year.

Not facts lf you arc being “ sold’’ on converting your heat­ ing system to some other type, move cautiously. 
The salesman's claims are not necessarily facts, regardless of Ins appar­ ent logic. 
The realities can best judged by calling iii a salesman of competing types of systems, sug­ gests the Better Heat* ing-(’noting Council, and present him with the claims the other fellow made. After you’ve heard troth sides, you will Im* iii a better position to judge what is Irest for y o u .
