Great den, 
Neal Eubanks! 

Don't he surprised it someone tells you how great your Great America nome looks. Because at 
Great America, we believe you can see the difference quality makes. 
In our garden kitchens, with handfinished cabinets and top quality appliances. In our roomy living areas, with vaulted cathedral ceilings, built-in bookcases and woodburn- tng fireplaces. In our lavish ceramic tile baths, with marble vanities and decorator appointments. 
Even in our generous mas­ ter suites, with private baths and walk-in closets. 
Everywhere you look, there is careful attention to design, styling, practicality and energy-efficiency. 
But that's only tne inside story. Outside, Great 
America homes are strikingly individualistic. Each home is designed for its particular homesite. Some are traditional, others reflect the informality of California styling. Some have soaring rooflines, cedar trim and 

 second-story balconies. 
Others are simple, yet ele­ gant. But all are equally suited to entertaining and day-to-day family living. 
You'll find these really great homes in San 
Antonio's finest com­ munities. In Northwest 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Park Forest, 
Hidden Creek, Forest Oak 
Estates, and now, 
Elm Creek. In North 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Thousand 
Oaks, The Oaks in 
San Pedro Hills, and 
Hidden Forest. Each community is minutes from excellent schools, near major shopping and employment centers. 
Prices range from the upper-4o's to S1oo,o(X). 
Visit these fine communities today and look for our new red, white and blue signs. For additional informa­ tion on a particular community, call 69o-o3oo. The really great homes in San Antonio are Great America homes, just ask any of our homeowners.

By FRANK M ANI P E L L I 

PRESIDENT, GREATER S A RUDDERS ASSOCIATION 
Some of the underlying causes in the increases in the cost of housing need to be clarified. 
Many families are being priced out of the housing market, and there are no simple, quick means to relieve the situation. 

Several factors 

Involved are several factors: an un­ certain economy, inflation, surging land costs, governmental regulation and red tape. Not the least of these is the governmental aspect. 

The hard costs (labor and material costs) today account for less than half the sales price of a typical single-fam­ ily home, having dropped from 54 per cent in 197o. the major reason for this change in ratio has been the sharp upturn in the price of raw land and land development costs, which to­ gether account for about 21 per cent of the total cost of a new home today. In the 197U-74 period, land costs increased til per cent. 

High financing costs must be men­ tioned. Because the typical builder is a small businessman, lie must borrow construction money at rates much higher than the prime rate. During the 
1974-75 money crunch, builders were paying as high as 17 per cent interest on their construction loans. In the 
197o-74 period alone, construction fin­ ancing costs for builders jumped an astronomical IHS per cent. This goes into the price of the house, 

A prime culprit in the scene is over-regulation by government — federal, state and local. For example, communities impose restrictive zoning ordinances (large lot zoning and mini­ mal floor requirements, bans against multi-family housing and the like) iii ail attempt to slow or stop new deve­ lopment. The result is to curtail home

• Concrete foundation 
• Quality kiln dried lumber by

• Owens Corning fiberglass insulation 6 " 3!6 ”, 
• Deluxe Magic Chef built in kitchen 

• Friedrich central air conditioning by Hairy Ciosland

Buz Sawyer 

494-2743 

CLASSIFIED D ISPLA Y 
CLASSIFIED D IS PLA Y 

 construction and make it more expen­ sive. 

These restrictive zoning ordinances or bans against additional sewer hoo­ 

 kups push suburban sprawl even further into outlying districts where new sewer systems, utilities, schools, roads and other municipal services must be built from scratch. Obv iously. it is much less expensive to build a new home in a developed community where sewer and other municipal facilities already have been built and can ac­ commodate additional growth. 

Then there's governmental overlap­ ping which adds red tape, causes delay and adds to cost. Building codes are designed to protect the health and sa­ fety of consumers. The Greater San 
Antonio Builders Association agrees with that wholeheartedly. But today many homes must meet not just one building standard but sometimes two or three. FHA-financed homes, for in­ stance. must conform to the federal government’s Minimum Property 
Standards as well as strong local or state building codes. 

A builder must wrestle with such matters as zoning ordinances with minimum floor area and lot size re­ quirements, tree ordinances, site plan reviews, environmental impact state­ ments, subdivision development stan­ dards such as road pavement and sidewalk widths, storm water management programs and water and sewer system requirements. Then there are the grading and sediment control regulations and arbitrarily im­ posed development and processing fees. 

One unnecessary regulation may add only $5o to the price of a home. But 2o such regulations imposed over a period 

CLASSIFIED D ISPLA Y 

 of years can easily add thousands of dollars to the price. 
The average homebuilder is a small businessman who constructs less than 
2o homes a year. He has little or no staff But it requires experts, lawyers aud others to cope with tile massive paperwork and red tape resulting from ever-expanding government regula­ tion. These costs must be passed on to the homebuyer. 
Consumers have a right to be con­ cerned, even as builders are con­ cerned. over rising housing costs. Help may be on tIn* way, but it will tie a long time before its effects will be felt . 

 stated 

Legislation has been proposed to force congressional action on basic re­ gulatory reform — a bill which would require Congress, w ithin four years, to complete reform of federal regulation iii many areas, including construction 
What with the elections this year, it is not likely that this legislation will get off the ground very soon. 
However, I believe that citizens should In1 alert to the critical problems of over-regulation. It affects their pocketbooks and their way of life and wlien they understand that, then they eau tell the politicians how they feel about it

V O L U M E 

Express-New s analysis 

MONDAY — Bluer chips led a re­ bound from the six-weeks drop of 7.113 in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. 
Six of the Dow stocks made the most active list, and the average posted a rise of ti.981, biggest gain since Jan l l 
In the whole market, however, ad­ vances were only slightly ahead of de­ clines and volume at 19.23o.9oo shares was the lowest of the year. 

TUESDAY — Again the emphasis was on blue chips, with the Dow aver­ age showing a percentage gain more than twice that of the whole market 
The D JIA rose 5 99 or o til per cent against a rise of ll la or o.27 per cent for the N Y SE index of all common stocks. Economic news included a 19 iper cent jump in new car sales drop of 
I per cent industrial output in January, attributed to severe weather and the gas shortage. 
WEDNESDAY — American Tele- phone, world’s most widely held stock, boosted its quarterly dividend by IO cents to $1 o5. This helped push the 
DJIA up for a rise of IO I beday. Volume imporved slights 

THI RSDAY — 
After advancing 
16.78 in three days, the DUA backed 

 off, posting a loss of 4 57. Volume was light as* modest profit taking was not offset by any fresh buying stimulus. 
The day’s trading at 19.o4o.ooo was slightly lower than Monday’s, which was the lowest of the year up to then. 

FRID AY 
— Trading fell to the lowest volume (18.o4o.ooo shares) since November 3o The desultory ses- sion virtually ignored a government report that consumer prices rose twice 

 a s fast iii January a s i i i December. Tile 
D JIA closed off 3 49 

St MM SRV — As measured by the 
Dow Jones Industrial Average, the market staged its first weekly adv ance in the seven weeks of 1977. But steam ran out at the rally in mid-week. Vo­ lume for the week was the lowest for any week shares. 

N EW YO RK (A P ) - The stock market responded to news of a jump in the government’s consumer price in­ dex with a slow decline Friday. 
The Dow Jones average of 3o indus­ trial stocks slipped 3.49 to 94o.24, reducing its gain for the week to 8,72 points. 
C onsum er prices up last m onth 

WASHINGTON (A P ) — Consumer prices increased eight-tenths of one per cent in January, the biggest infla­ tionary surge in 18 months, and go­ vernment economists warned Friday of another big increase in February and possibly March. 
President Carter also was handed unfavorable reports 
Frid ay on workers’ earnings, on the cost of housing and on growth in the nation’s 
Gross National Product, all of which could make ii more difficult for him to achieve his economic goals this year 
Higher costs for food and fuel led to the price surge in January. Overall food costs were up nine-tenths of one per cent, more than the increase of six-tenths of one per cent during all of 
1976 
Furthermore, the Labor Department said its January Consumer Price Index did not reflect the full price impact of the severe winter weather. That probably will show up in the price report for February and possibly 
March, said one top government econ­ omist 
But even though prices increased iii 
January at an annual rate of nearly IO per cent. Maynard Comic/ of the 
Commerce Department said he thinks the underlying inflation rate probably is still between 5 per cent and Ii per cent. Consumer prices rose 4 8 per cent during all of 1976.

Bus usage drops 

Not as many people rode the bus last month as did in January a year ago. trustees of the San 
Antonio 
Transit 
Authority (SATS) were told Friday. 
F. Norman Hill. the general manager, said the number of bus pass­ engers dropped by more than five per cent 
He attributed the de­ crease to “ business con­ ditions** and not the had weather. 

The trustees awarded a 
$13,876 contract to Tri- 
Tex Machine & Tool Co for a piece of equipment; and a $723 a month con­ tract to Alamo Building 
Maintenance for janitor­ ial services. 

The resignation of Ms 
Cheramv Kushuldt. a trustee, was accepted with regret. She is mov­ ing to Kansas City, Mo., to accept a new job 
Trustees met in dosed session following tile re­ gular meeting, un- inturned nothing aud ad­ journed

WASHINGTON (A P ) 
— The Ryder System, 
Inc., a nationwide truck rental firm, has agreed to refund up to $1.5 mil­ lion to onetime students w ho were trained to drive* trucks and heavy equip­ ment at vocational schools operated by the company. 
The court-enforced pact. publicly announced 
Friday, settles a Federal 
Trade Commission com­ plaint which alleged that the firm misled enrollees alioth their chances for employ meta.

Court tells firm to halt letter use 

 tienss NEWS CAPITOL BuktAU 
A San Antonio-based eviction firm has been enjoined from sending nut notice letters bearing the alleged signature of state Atty. Gen. John L Hill nr his assistants 
The injunction was granted late Thursday by 166th 
State Bist Judge Peter Michael Curry against F. A i 
Brown, doing business us Original Notice to Quit I 
Agency, 
In the Bexar County suit. Hill alleged the defen­ dant sent out letters announcing establishment ut his business aud attached to the announcements a letter purported to have been released over the signature I of Hill and ills assistants 
The state contended the lefter til fact was not sent out over Hill's or his assistant's signature* hut was a letter pieced together by the defendant. 
The suit charged the pieced-together letter was part of tine used by the Bexar County Legal Aide 
Assn., and a portion of a legal opinion rendered bv 
Hill. 
In addition to prohibiting use of the letter, Brown was also ordered to furnish the court all names of businesses and individuals to whom the original letter was sent.

I D 15 4oo 5 5o tbs i i i l l 

Declines held a 7-5 edge on advances af the New York Stock Exchange. 
Big Board volume slowed to 18.o4 million shares from 19.o4 million 
Thursday, hitting a 2%month low for the second straight session. 
Most of the day’s loss came at the outset after the Labor Department reported that the consumer price index climbed o.8 per cent—equal to a 9.6 per cent annual rate—last month 
Largest in year 

The rise, led by sharply higher prices for food and fuel, was the lar­ gest for the cost-of-living yardstick in a year and a half. 
And the government cautioned that it did not reflect the full effect of bad winter weather on prices. 
The news depressed prices in the bond market, which is especially sen­ sitive to inflation trends, and thus ad­ dl'd rising long-term interest rates to the stock market’s problems. 
Despite those negative influences, no heavy selling of stocks appeared, how­ ever. In the afternoon the market sim­ ply drifted before Wall Street closed down for a three-day holiday weekend. 
First gain 
The Dow’s gain for the week was its first this year after a string of six consecutive declines since Now 5'('ar s. 
Standard & Poor’s index of 4o6 in­ dustrials was down .53 at 111.57 on the day. and S&P's 5oo-stock composite index gave up ,43 o 1oo.49 
Inexeo Oil was the most active issue as of the NYSE close at 4 p.m., up •’% at 
21% on turnover of close to 4oo,ooo shares. 
Tile company said it had no explan­ ation for the stock's runup this week on heavy turnover. Analysts say traders have been attracted to the stock by the company’s natural gas and other en­ ergy interests. 
Inmont, second on the active list, v aulted 4:Vi to 21%. Esmark has offered 
$22.5o a share for the company’s stock, and Inmont said it had received ex­ pressions of interest from other, un­ named companies 
Esm ark, which separately an­ nounced plans to close five of its Swift 

& Do. meat plants because of poor earnings, dipped % to 32%. 
Polaroid also was actively traded, rising 1% to 35% on expectations that the company will introduce an instant, movie system at its annual meeting in 
April. 
Murphy Oil slumped 3% to 26%. The company said its earnings would be 

Coffee futures rise 12 cents 

Trading was active again this 

 week in coffee futures as prices rose to the $2.52 per pound level basis the May delivery for a week s gain of over 12 cents per pound. 
A Central American producer raised her minimum export price by an equi­ valent of 7.25 cents per pound, lending impetus to the upmove in futures, and 
Brazil raised her minimum exporter assessment $4 per bag, offsetting a further small devaluation in her currency, the iruzlero. 

Cocoa drops 

Af thf same time, cocoa futures suf­ fered a severe decline due in a variety of unfavorable factors. 
A labor strike iii the Netherlands disrupted Hit' normal flow of cocoa beans aud products iii and out of their ports, throwing the European trade into a tailspin 
Since the Dutch are major cocoa merchants til tins part of the world, the shortage of supplies reverberated throughout Western Europe, forcing 

COMMODITY 
REPORT 
Furnished by <5*raid S. 
( ohn. vice president. sales division. San An­ tonio office, Ruche Hal­ sey Stuart Inc. 

 some manufacturers to suspend their operations. 
By Friday, cocoa for May delivery had declined to the $1.64 per pound level for a fifteen cent loss on the week 
By contrast, trading in sugar was quiet, with nearby delivery posting small losses. 
During the last two weeks there has been sideways activity us fresh input has been lacking.

Gold gains in London 
CM 

LONDON (A P) - The price of gold rose in London Friday while the dollar made its most substantial gain against the weakened French franc. 

 undertainties were largely respond for the franc’s weakness ihle 

(•old rose 2o cents an ounce in 
London, closing ai $136 75, up from 
Thursday’s $136,55. 

Marketplace 

OMC T R I(K S

TINDALL k SON 
Pontiac, GML 

In Zurich, Europe’s major bullion center, the price remained unchanged at $136 625 an ounce. 

The French franc eased against all major currencies for the second day in a row The dollar, winch was quoted at 
4 99 francs for the first time in four weeks, dosed at 4 9875 francs in limit­ ed trading in Paris, up front Thurs­ days closing rate of 4 98 francs 

The dollar gained slightly against the pound, closing ut $1.7o45 as com­ pared with Thursday’s close of $1 7o54 

 rile stability of tin* pound was more remarkable considering it came af tor the announcement of a sharp increase in January’s retail prices here

IS H 

REFLECTED BEAUTY 

A m e rica s Sp ace Sh uttle rid e s a to p a g ia n t 7 4 7 on its first test fligh t 
Space shuttle airborne 

 f t 
North Star Mall 
FCSTIVAL OF FMC ARTS 

THRU THE 26TH 

2nd Semi-Annual Invitational Artists' Tour 

Come to North Star Mall Feb. 16 thru 26 and 

 enjoy a festival of fine arts throughout the Mall. 
Artists and craftspersons from all over the U.S. will display, and have on sale, their works along with a tremendous participation of Texas artists. Oils, watercolor, pottery, jewelry, metal sculpture, photography, and woodcarving just to give you an example of the variety of media and talent there! 

COS A N G U ES TIMES SERVICE 

EDW ARDS A FB, Calif. - The space shuttle, destined to be­ come the Conestoga wagon of spaee-travel, made its maiden flight here Friday morning — a two-hour-long jaunt on the back of a modified 747 jumbo jet. 

The flight was a cautious first test of the combined Boeing 747 mothership and the Rockwell International shuttle orbiter. 
At an altitude of IK,OOO feet and speeds of up to 287 rn.p h., the flight was far short of the orbital altitudes 
(between 115 and KIK! miles above the earth) and speeds l ’p to 17,2oo m p h.) for which the shuttle was designed. 
W ith National Aeronautics and Space 
Administration pilots Fitzhugh I, 
Fulton and Thomas C. McMurtry at the controls, of the big. silvery 747. the mothership was cleared to take oil at 
8:3o a m. by tin* Edwards control tower. 
“ She s rolling." one of the pilots re­ ported. as the 747’s brakes were re­ leased and the mothership began to mo\ e. 

T -.V i c a u g h t the o th e r it tim e s, the T I c a m e r a tm in n 

 it a r t in g a lo n g s id e the m o t h e r sh ip in p ig g y b a c k e d shuttle lik e b r ig h t ly st r ip e d t r o p ic a l fish s u i m m i n g c lo se to a g r o u p e r 

Despite the great weight of the two vehicles — 265,35o kilograms (585.(MIO pounds) combined — the jumbo jet quickly gathered speed and lifted ea­ s i ly off the runway at about the 
6.(HK)-foot mark. 
The big aircraft, with the shuttle orbiter securely fastened to the top of its fuselage by a series of struts, was accompanied during the takeoff and throughout the subsequent flight by a quartet of T-38 chase aircraft. 
Two of the chase planes were flown bv NASA points Richard ll. Truly and 
.loc ll Engle, who some day will fly the shuttle orbiter in space. 

Remarkable 

Television cameras aboard the T-38s prov ided a series of remarkable v iews of the 747-shuttle combination as the two vehicles ran through their paces high above the Mohave Desert. 
At times, the TY camera on one T-38 

 caught the other T-38s darting along­ side the mothership in piggybacked shuttle like brightly striped tropical fish swimming close to a grouper. 
This initial flight test, the first of six in which the cabin of the shuttle or­ biter will be unmanned, was intended to evaluate the low-speed performance and handling characteristics of the composite vehicle. 
Although pilot Fulton reported some 
"very, very slight buffeting in the rear 
(of the 747)" at one point early in the flight, he also reassured ground con­ 

 trollers it was ‘ nothing to worry about." 
Later. .John Yardley, the NASA as sedate administarator for space flight, speculated that the buffeting may have been caused by a very slight misa­ lignment of tilt1 Shuttle on the back of tin' /4c 
The 747 returned to earth at 111:35 a m., a little more than two hours after it took off. and a NASA spokesman said that “ almost all of the major test ob­ jectives” were met. 
The remaining five unmanned shut­ tle flights are to be made over the next month or so and then, in May, pilots will'begin riding inside the space ve­ hicle as the 747 carries the black, gray and white vehicle — called the Enter­ prise — on still another series til cap­ tive flights. 

New political group created on North Side 

A new citizens political or­ ganization was on the drawing hoards Friday. 

It is called the North San Antonio 
Political Education Assn., and the announcement of its founding came out in North San Antonio Chamber of 
C ommerce envelopes. 
President of the association is Terry c. Tippen. 
Invitation 
The letter invites citizens to a meet­ ing at 7 p m Thursday at 2446 Cee Gee, 
Suite 1o4. North San Antonio Chamber of Commerce Executive board room 
Asserting "we can no longer afford the luxury of letting someone else manage our hard bought freedom," 
Tippen cited the need for the organization 
He explained an organization is 
Hooded to educate the public and de­ fine the issues, to maintain continuity; to search tor candidates; to orion can­ didates and top staff, to recommend sound campaign finance practices and assist in finding contributors, and to recommend practices for the recruiting and training of volunteer help. 
Positive 

Stressing financial contributions are not the interest of the new effort. Ttp- pon said instead the organization is looking for people with positive atti­ tudes and physical commitment. 
Ile said the organization hopes to Im* a |M»sitive influence in the future of San 
Antonio. Texas and the nation. 
Tippers letter opens with this ques­ tion: 

"How often have you sat back in pure amazement at some of the unbe­ lievable actions and statements of some of our elected public officials?” 

James Dement. North San Antonio 
Chamber of ( oinmeree president, is an announced candidate for City Council 

Nielsen, 
Webb open up offices 

Asserting he wants to make District 
2 "a showplace for San Antonio " City 
( oiincil Candidate Joe Webb opened his campaign headquarters Friday. 
The headquarters is located at 527 
Center St 
A l s o opening his campaign head­ quarters Friday was Councilman I) ford Nielsen. Nielsen is seeking re­ election from District 8. 
Webb, a candidate in District 2, promised he would work for a program to reduce crime, to provide job oppor­ tunities. to reduce the hardship from high utility costs and to increase needed public services in the area 
Addressing his supporters at an open house at his headquarters at 6222 111 IU in the 222 Building, Nielsen pledged he will continue working towards deve­ lopment o| the human and economic resources in District 8 and all of San 
Antonio 
Mayor asks closer neighborhood links 

Mayor Lila Cockrell Friday set a goal of building mutual respect and cooperation among the various neigh­ borhoods and insulation groups of the city. 
Speaking to more than IOO sup- 
(Millers at the opening of her North 
Side headquarters iii the North Crown 
Building, the mayor said the city must make wise use of all of its natural resources, including its people, 
"We are growing as a*city," she said, "and there is a great need to protect our heritage and presene the quality ut hie " 
Different neighborhoods have differ­ ent needs, said the mayor, calling for 
"every effort to see that all sections of our city participate in the general growth a n d development." 
Mrs Cockrell railed for the im ­ provement of services i i i older neighborhoods as well as the extension 

\ 

 oi needed services to newer areas. 
She then said that the greatest re­ source of the city is its people. She added: 
"W e want to build bridges of under­ standing among all of the people iii our community so that regardless of the section, or of the ethnic or cultural background our citizens can reach out to each other ii i mutual respect and cooperat ion." 

Present at the dedication w ire tonner mayor Walter McAllister and a group of former council members in­ cluding Mike Passur. Mrs Manfred 
Gerbardt, Jack Kaufman. Bob Jones and George De l*a Garza 
The mayor had spent much of the day campaigning starting with a breakfast with 25 business and profes­ sional people and a mid-morning coffee break Iii the Jefferson area

Saturday February 19 1977 

Texas reports flu 

ATLANTA (A P) — Influenza out­ breaks have been reported in 14 states, including widespread outbreaks in four states, the national Center for Di­ sease Control said Friday. 
The outbreaks involve Influenza B. a less severe virus which strikes chil­ dren and young adults. 
However, additional A-Yietoria in­ fluenza has been reported, ineluding 

 two eases confirmed by laboratory tests at the University of Alabama al 
Tuscaloosa. The CDF said increases in school absenteeism in Tuscaloosa also has been reported. 
Widespread outbreaks of Influenza B were reported in Alabama, Arkansas, 
Pennsylvania and Connect lent, with regional outbreaks in Colorado, Texas and Florida.

The musician has been wanting to do something for television for some time. But he never could come up with the right project. He gave it three tries, but scrapped what hi' had each time.

On the Air 

Bv LLDYX PAPPAS 

TV Editor 

 because I had been on the road for a long time.” the performer said during a recent press conference al NHC Studios iii Los 
Angeles. “ I wanted to get back to real life, out of the spotlight, get to know my family again.” 
“ It was tin* best four years of my life,” he continued. “ The most productive. “ lit* said he spent the time oil the beach, catching up on Ins life and writing music. 
In early 197(5. Diamond decided it w as t hue to resume bis concert car­ eer and (hose to do so iii 
Australia and New Zea­ land. where he had never performed before. He played to record crowds. 
Then it was back to the 
U.S. and attendance - breaking records iii Las 
\ egos. New York and Los 
Angeles. 
Young musician 
Diamond was born in 
Brooklyn iii 1943. He be­ gan his musical career at 
Hi when he was given a second-hand guitar as a birthday present by his parents. 
He entered New X’ork 
University as a pre med major on a fencing scho­ larship. He also turned to performing as a means of getting his music played and heard 
Before, he finished col­ lege. 
Diamond was signed to write music for 
$5o a week, so he quit school to embark on a career as a composer. 
He found it was not all roses. however, and for 
Hie next several years bad mort* rejections than acceptance of bis musical scores. 
Recordings 
Finally, out of desper­ ation. the singer-com- poser returned to per­ forming in the hopes of getting his music heard. 
While playing at a 
Greenwich Village coffee house, record producers 
Je ff Barry and billie 
Greenwich heard him and signed him to a con­ tract. At his first record­ ing session for the Bang 
Record label, he record­ ed three of his songs which became lilts. 
These included “ Solitary 
M an.” one of the numbers he will be doing iii the special Monday evening. 
’’Cherry. 
Cherry” and ” 1 Got a 
Feeling.” 
Later the musician signed with Urn Records, which later merged into 

 the MCA Records label. 
He was with them for nearly five years and produced eight albums, all of which reached gold status ($l million iii sales). 
Of his music. Diamond said, 
“ I am not pi­ geonholed so I can write any kind. There are no solid lines drawn.” 

Then he added. “ Music today is very broad. Not limited to one thing like in the ’5os.” 
Drug scene 
W hen asked if he felt a stand which he took se­ veral years ago on drugs hurt his career, he ad­ mitted he thought it did. 
“ It hurt my career for a while.” he commented. 
“ but I have no regrets for what I did “ 
"Unfortunately, the drug scene is still around but not like it was.” In* added, ” 1 don’t think there is anything wrong with pot. alcohol, etc., if you're old enough to handle it. But we're talk­ ing about 15-year-olds.” 
During the musical program, Diamond pulls three well-known figures from his audience — He­ len 
Reddy. 
Henry 
W inkier and Los Angeles' 
Mayor Tom Bradley. All three join him iii a musi­ cal number. 
Iii addition to the te­ lex ision show. Diamond also taped a new concert album. "Lo ve at the 
Greek” which bas been released. He’s hoping for another gold.

The Trinity University public relations staff has added Jack Landman as coordinator of broadcast and film. 
A graduate of Trinity in 1974. Landman joined 
Trinity'* journalism , broadcasting and film department in 
H)74 to teach a basic film pro­ duction class. He also directed and produced special documentary films. One of his recent productions.

FORECAST 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday February 19 1977 

South T exas gets milder 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
A mild cold front moved slowly into southern portions of Texas Friday bringing milder tempera­ tures to the region. 
The front was reaching from southeast to South­ west Texas. 
-North of the front, temperatures were in the arts late in the morning, but some areas were reporting readings in the fibs. 
Northerly winds prevailed north of the front and southerly winds were the rule south of the front with wind speeds ranging from five to IO miles per hour. 
The National Weather Service said the forecast was for mild temperatures Saturday under mostly clear skies.

USO’s role in peace praised

The LSO may actually be more important in peacetime than during war. according to the organization's national executive director. 
M ichael E . M onster was guest speaker at tile USO Council of Metro­ politan San Antonio's With annual meeting this week. 
“ Our sole purpose is to bridge the gap between civ.ilian and m ilitary life,” Monster said. . 
“ Most people think of the USO in terms of periods of war. but we feel there is more need for that link between military and civilian worlds during times of peace.” 
Monster said since the end of the 
Vietnam war, I SOs worldwide have grown smaller and funding is harder to come by. 
Work harder 
“ It just means we have to work a little harder to maintain our posture us the organization with it* sole concern being the welfare of military personnel and their families.” lie said. 
The USO is funded through United 
Way. 
Mrs. R N W hite was elected presi­ dent of the USO council during the luncheon meeting. She has been active 

 with USO for 14 years and is the first woman to be elected to the office. 
Arthur Riklin was elected vice pres­ ident, M rs. George VV. B ich sel, treasurer and Mrs Charles I Castro 
.lr., secretary. 
Engineering seminar set 

The San Antonio Institute oil Minor­ ities in Engineering will conduct a seminar from 8 a.m. to I p.m. Satur­ day in the Sams Athletic Center at 
Trinity University. 
Co sponsors are the Intercultural 
Development Research Assn.. Trinity 
University and San Antonio School 
District. 
Following a welcome bv Mayor Lila 
Cockrell at 8:4o a.m.. R. F. Tickner. of 
Exxon Co. and T A M E chairman, will speak. 
Panel discussions topics will include 
"M inorities in Engineering 
Ail 
Historical Survey and Summary of 
Progress" and "The Role til Techno­ logy-Based Industry in Minority Edu­ cation 
— 
The 
Consum er's 
Perspective." 
A blood clot the size of this dot can cause a heart attack. 

O ra stroke. 

Every year, thousands die because of a blood clot. I housands more become disabled, some permanently. 
W h a t’s being done to stop it? 
Plenty. 

W e ’re the Am erican Heart Association. W e ’re giving scientists the chance to find out more about blood clots. 

How to detect them. How to treat them. How to keep them from happening. 
W e ’re fighting hard. W ith new drugs. New kinds oi treatment. Better ways to help heart attack and stroke victim s return to a norm al life. 

And it’s only a part of tile total w ar w e’re waging against the number one cause of death in this country: cardiovascular d iseases. 

Bu t we can’t fight without your money. W hen an Am erican H eart A s s o c i­ 

 ation volunteer asks for your dollars, he generous. 
The blood clot is sm all, the problem is enormous. 
Give. 
Its a simple case of self-defense. 
American Heart Association

SURVIVE DIVORCE 
They are organizing, America's divorced husbands ... to achieve financial equity, fair play and emotional well-being. In 
"Men and Divorce: From No-Fault to No Future,'' author Robert 
Cassidy takes a sensitive look at divorce. He gives you a sensitive look at the child's side of divorce, urges men to express their feelings in the interest of personal growth ... shows them how to relate to intimates once more.

H u n ger sp o tligh ted 

Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of San 
Antonio will give special attention to the prob­ lems of world hunger throughout Lent this year. 
Ender the sponsorship of Archbishop Francis 
-I. Furey, a special collection will be taken Sun­ day in all Catholic churches to support the annual 
Catholic Relief Services appeal 
A supplemental program of Lenten prayer, fasting and alm sgiving, known as “ Operation 
Rice Bow l.” will be conducted throughout the entire Lent season. 

Catholics and ot hers will be asked to eat one frugal meal once a week during Lent and donate the savings from this meal to "Operation Rice 
Bowl.” 
Yet C R S spent less than five cents out of every dollar from the collecion on administrative costs. 

Anyone wishing to support this great humani­ tarian effort should contribute during the Lenten season at the local Catholic church.

I Lets, Sunset Memorial toil

Two persons have died following separate F r i­ day morning traffic acci­ dents 
Police identified the victims as Dawn Bort ag. 
17, of 554 T im b e rlan e 
Drive, and Carlos Flores. 
27, of UH Mascasa St. 
The teen-ager was killed after an eastbound car in which she was riding on the 11141o ac­ cess road at 
H arry 
Wurzbach Highw ay slid into a guard rail about 3 a.m., police said. 
The victim, who was thrown from the car. was pronounced dead on arri­ val at 3:5o a m. at North­ east Baptist Hospital. 
The driver of the car. 
Jo Ann Cervantes, 18, of 

1188 Gal i tty Road. was undergoing treatment at a local hospital for rela­ tively minor injuries, po­ lice said 
The other accident oc­ 

 curred about two hours e arlie r when 
F lo re s' northbound automobile on 39th Street collided with a westbound car at 
Commerce Street. 

Dangerous chemical spills 

C IN C IN N A T I (A P ) — About 7o tons of the dan­ gerous chemical carbon tetrachloride flowed into the 
Ohio River from West Virginia on Friday, endan­ gering drinking water between Parkersburg, VV.Va. and Louisville, Ky. 
The Environmental Protection Agency said the chemical mass was 75 miles long. Traveling at a rate of 12 miles a day, it was near Portsmouth, Ohio, 
Friday night. At that speed, it would reach Cincin­ nati in five days. 
Joseph Harrison, chief of water supply branch of the E P A ’s regional office in Chicago, said the chemical entered the Ohio River from West Virgin­ ia’s Kanawha River. 

Officers identified the* driver of the other ear as 
Auturo M Moreno. 31. or 
H815 Woodflame St. M or­ eno was treated and re­ leased at Baptist Hospi­ tal. 
Flores was pro­ nounced dead at Green 
H ospital fo llo w in g the accident.

Charger SE really special 

SP O R T Y L O O K is fe a tu re d b y the sp e cia l ed itio n D o d g e C h a rg e r 
Motorists offered tax help 

Rules governing "h a t motorists may deduct from federal income tov because of car ownership are explained in a new edition of “ Automobile Income Tax De­ ductions.” recently published by the 
American Automobile Association. 
The eight-page pamphlet first discusses the question of whether an automobile is used for business or personal affairs, or a combination of both. 
Although most deductions fall under business use. aud much of tip' pamphlet is devoted to these deductions, there are also ways given to save tax money on an 
^•immobile owned solely for personal use. 

Depreciation 

Two methods for depreciation of motor vehicles used in business are discussed, including the straight line and double declining balance methods. 
Iii addition, there is a section on tax implications of sale or exchange of auto­ mobiles used for either business or per­ sonal affairs 
I he 1977 edition of “ Automobile Income 
Tax Deductions" is available free from m ost local A A A c lu b s or In w ritin g 
\m erican Automobile Association. Public 
R e latio n s Dept.. K ill G atehouse Rd.. 
Falls Church. Va. 22942 

C IA SSW IO DISPLAY 

A U O DEALER H ONORED 

Charles G. Orsinger, center, president of Charles Orsinger Buick Co., receives an award honoring bim as one of only I 2 automobile dealers in the nation selected as a Regional Representative for the Time Magazine Quality Dealer Award (TM Q DA) program for 1977. Making the presentation in New Orleans at the 6oth annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Assn. (NADA), which cooperates with Time in the awards program, is Michael M. Carey, left, director of the T M Q D A program, assisted by Minda Welch, general manager of San Antonio Automobile 
Dealers Assn. 

ClASyfltB-BfSPlAY 

Bs JIM V K K O IT 
AUTO EDITOR 
The 1977 Dodge Charger SE 
(special edition) has a lot to offer anyone looking for a personal sporty-ear. The ear is more luxur­ ious than sporty — a neat hit of deception on Dodge's part but it still has enough handling to please most drivers 
F o r this road report we picked up a 
Charger from Cliff W hile of North Star 
Dodge. 7242 San Pedro The car was well equipped with the options most people would want. and a few extra goodies too. 
The interior featured a six-way power front seat. upholstered in a beautiful crushed velour, with a pull down center arm rest. B y m an ip u la tin g the power controls, and adjusting the tilt steering wheel, it is possible to find a very com ­ fortable drivm g position 
The tost car was equipped with inside remote controls for both right and left outside rearview m irrors. The right hand m irror control is a real convenience for anyone driving a car for the first time as it allows the driver to gel full benefit from the m irror 
Fuel pacer 

W e have co m m ented before on the 
Dodge fuel-pacer system, hut it is worth another mention. On the top of the left hand fender is a yellow light thai serves a dual purpose ii flashes with the turn sig ­ nal and it also turns on to inform the driver that he is using a large amount of gas. 
The device is vacuum operated so when you push down on the gas pedal it lights up 
N o special effort is required on the part of the drivel — you never have to look down at the dash, tIn* light is out there right where you can sec ii all the time. It s easy to get use to. and if you want to increase your around town m i­ leage. it could add many m iles per gallon. 
Now more and m on' people are order­ ing their new cars with speed control de­ vices The control for the Dodge system is combined with the turn signal stalk and is easy to use. It also allows you to touch the brake to slow down. and if you want lo resum e the sam e speed, inst move the control device and the system will pick 
.jack up to till' pre-set speed 
Digital clock 
There was also a digital electronic clock mounted in th** dash at an angle inst right for the driver to see. I have never been very big on car clocks, hut these new electronic models do provide time with a high degree of accuracy. 
Other extras included a unique power door lock system , A M - F M stereo, air conditioning, automatic transm ission— iii 

THE D O D G E C H A R G E R SE 

 short, just about everything you would want for a loaded' ear. 
From the perform ance standpoint the m ost im p ortan t option w as the 
MO cubic-inch V K engine. The :tlK is the standard engine for Charger and would provide better gas mileage, but the larger 
V K is mote in keeping with the type of ear 
( barger is. One could go one step beyond arid order the 4oo-eiibie-iiich ‘lean burn’ 
\ K which should prov ide even mort1 ex­ citement. 

Handling case 

Although we were plagued bv rain dur­ ing most ol the time we were driving the 
( barger, we found it easy to handle on the wet pavements, hut because things were wet we had to leave out the cornering and braking sections. 
We surm ise the Charger would provide good braking, it certainly did well ii i the ruin, aud we believe you would find the ear u n d e rste e rin g to a c o n sid e ra b le degree. 
The suspension, using torsion bars lip front and unsym m etrical leaf springs in the rear, with anti-sway bars both front and rear gives tin* type of ride most peo­ ple like best. ll is very smooth on the freeways, takes 
San Antonio streets very nicely, and han­ dled a couple of nasty chuck-ho les i i i stride 

Q u ie tn e s s 

The interior is reasonably well insulat­ ed from outside noises. There is some radial tire thump on railroad tracks and tar seams, but the general im pression is

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday February 19 197/ 

D A T S U N 'S 8 1 o sta tio n w a q o n has high le v e ls of lu x u ry and e co n o m y 
Datsun offers new models 

THE 5-SPEED SO PSX is D atsun'* first e n try in the sports cou pe field 

A sports tor xvii Ii everything except a sports ear price? That's 

 what Datsun is calling the all-new 
2oo-SX sporty compact. 

How about a liixurs ear with the engine 
••I the famed *24o-7? That s Datsun s new 
Kill series — the tup of tile line model III sedan and station wagon versions. 
These are the newest Datsuns lo be ap­ pearing at The Calmbach Co. i i i San An­ tonio. 
The four-door Kin sedan has a basic list 

 price of $5,o99. the 81o wagon is $5,499 and the ‘2oo-SX is $4,399 
The ‘2oo-SX is a specialty car available only as a two-door hardtop It’s a fastback with a chopped rear end. a 1952cc over­ head-cam engine and a standard five- speed transmission 
Despite a relatively short wheelbase 
<92-molies) the 2oo-SX has a long and low look accentuated by a unique “ character line’’ treatment. 
The 81o is a luxury sedan ii i the sports/touring tradition which replaces the OKI series in the Datsun lineup ll is 

 powered by Datsun's race-proven, fuel injected y-eylinder 24o-Z engine. 

Standard equipment on the SIO includes such features as a six-way adjustable d riv e r’s seal, quart/ d igital clock. 
.W I/FM sic* *n radio, new vinyl and cloth upholstery ,..:d a rear seat armrest (on the sedan model). 

The 81o sedan model also features a fully independent rear suspension for the sports-enthusiast driver who demands performance with luxury.

The Double Bonus Special is d e ig n ed *o p'ovide a reduced rote for individuals who wish to sell things they no longer need 
The special rote of 2 lines, 6 days $3 mokes it profitable lo advertise low-cost items sucTi as baby furniture or used appliances

BIDS WANTED 

1. Sealed bids addressed to the City 

Clerk. Qty Hall, San Antonio, Texas will 

 be received for CONSTRUCTION OF IM 

PROVFMFNTS ARD ADDITIONS TO THE 

CITY OF SAN ANTONIO, TEXAS, CON­ 

VENTION CENTER ARENA, in accordance 

 with plans ond specifications on file in 

 the office of James H Acosta, City 
Engineer, Engineering Division, Fourth 

Floor of City Hall 

2. Bids will be received of the oHice of the City Clerk, City of San Antonio, 

Texas, until 2oo oclock PM , on 

Friday, the 18th day of March, 1977, 

 and then publicly opened ond read. 

Any bids received after that time will 

 not be accepted. 

3 
The bids shall be submitted in 

 duplicate on Form 9-12 (Rev Feb 7o), 

Proposal to City of San AntonioThe 

 envelope containing any proposal 

 sholl be endorsed: "Bid on Additions to 

 the City of San Antonio, Texas, Con­ vention Center 

4 
Pions ond 
Specifications ore

Acosta, 
City Engineer, Fourth Floor, 

City Hall, Son Antonio, Texos, where 

 they may be examined without charge. A SOO OO deposit will be re­ 

 quired from any person toking said 

Plans ond Specifications out of said of­ 

 fice Additional instructions to bidders 

 aie contained in said 
Plans ond 

Specifications. 

S. A Cashier s Check or 8id Bond payable to the order of the City of Son 

Antonio, in the amount of not less 

 than FIVE PERCENT (S%) of the total 

 bid must accompany each bid in ac 

 cordance with the Instructions to Bid 

 dees 

6 The City reserves the right to reject 

 any ond all bids and waive any 

 formalities 

7 This is a proposed public works con­ 

 tract, ond Article 5159o, R C S Texos, as amended, requiring that not less 

 than the prevailing wage rate for work 

 of o simitar character in this locality 

 shall be paid all laborers, workmen, 

 and mechanics employed iii the con 

(traction thereof shall be complied with

12o BIDS 8 PROPOSALS 

A public hearing will be held Monday, 
February 28, 19/7, 84)o - 9-oo a.m., to review plans for continuation of the 
Education Service Center, Region 2o 
ESEA Title VII Bilingual Education Pro­ gram. The program involves training of sixty 
(6o1 teachers from the 
Edgewood, Harlondale, Carrizo Springs, 
Crystal City and San Felipe-Oel Rio In­ dependent School DBtncts. The hear­ ing will be held in the Center s Board 
Room af 155o N E loop 41o, Son An­ tonio, Texas. The proposal will be available For inspection beginning at 
3-oo p m , February 25, 1977 in the 
Center offices, I SSO N.E. loop 41o, Son 
Antonio, Texas. 
For additional in­ formation, call either Elvira P. Barrera or Dr. Noel Jackson at 828-3551.

Boss tapped as part o f fraud 
A Kelly AKB employe who pleaded guilty to falsifying travel vouchers Friday impli­ cated his supervisors. 
Claude Leroy Warden 
Sr. told a U.S. magis­ trate his supervisors arranged for the frau­ dulent hotel receipts he and others turned in for reimbursement in .Jan­ uary 1975. 
Warden is among 28 civilian employes at 
San Antonio area mili­ tary bases charged with fraudulent Iv demand­ ing payment from tin government.

 and Warden were both sentenced and given two-year probated sen­ tences and $1,ooo fines. 
U.S. Magistrate -Jo­ seph F. Leonard -lr imposed the probation­ ary terms on the condi­ tion tile two Kelly em­ ployes reimburse the government. 
Asst. I S Atty. VV 
Hay Jahn told Judge 
Leonard Warden and 
Rodriguez were among a group of 
Kelly workers who were as­ signed to temporary duty at bases in Texas and California. 
Warden said his supervisors would ar­ range with hotel em­ ployes to get receipts reflecting the regular price of rooms was paid. even though the 
Kelly workers received discounts because they were in a group. 

A c t io n 

Alf Force spokesman 
Joe Mt'Anally said F ri­ day disciplinary action may be taken against the convicted workers after all court action is completed 
He said tile adminis­ trative action could range from a letter of reprimand to suspen­ sion without pay to ter­ mination. 
‘ It will depend on the the amount of money involved.” M cAnally said. 
Jahn told 
Judge 
Leonard the govern­ ment is aware of W ar­ den s charges and the investigation is contin­ uing. 
Warden and Rodri­ guez bring to seven the total number of civil service employes con­ victed of the misdemeanor charge. 
Guilty rn plea nets 
2 years et 

A former 
IV s r 
County emplose plead­ ed guilty Friday to offi­ cial misconduct iii the use of public funds aud was assessed a two-year prison sentence 
Hist. Judge ll. F. 
“ Hippo” G arcia as­ sessed the sentence after Dolores I. Molina, 
:15. pleaded guilty to of­ ficial misconduct con­ cerning $l.L'tM> paid by lawyers to the district clerk’s office 
Mrs. 
Molina. a former deputy district clerk, was originally indicted by the Bexar 
County Grand Jury on charges of official mis­ conduct aud misappli­ cation of public funds. 
However, after she pleaded guilty to offi­ cial misconduct, the other charge was dropped by the district attorney's office. 
Mrs. Molina tailed to record the complete amount of fees the dis­ trict clerk's office re­ ceived for processing lawsuits while she was employed there, ac­ cording to a spokesman for the district attor­ ney's office.

W ehling must refund tuition 

By B K N K IN G Jr. 
A district judge ruled 
Friday a private busi­ ness school operator must pay back $927,ooo in tuition payments to 
1,5o5 former students. 

Hist 
Judge Robert 
M urray entered the judgment against Carl 
I) Wehling who ran a statewide chain of busi­ ness and vocational schools. The chain was based in San Antonio. 
Judge Murray also ruled Wehling must pay 

 a $1.oo11 civil fine in addition to repaying the loans. 
Earlier ruling 
Earlier (his month a 
45th District Court jury found the corporations which composed Weh- ing's chain did not function as true corpor­ ations and. as a result, 
Wehling is responsible for their actions. 
The attorney gener­ al's office sued Wehling for violations of consumer protection laws. 
Coin firms’ mail halted 

Two San Antonio mail order coin companies cannot receive mail concerning coin mail orders until the validity of fraud allegations against them is deter­ mined. 
U.S. Dist. Judge I). 
VV. Suttle issued a tem­ porary restraining order Friday authoriz­ ing the U S Postal Ser­ vice to hold up all mail addressed to Riverside 
Coin Co. and Security 
National Coin Corp. 
Postal 
Inspectors have filed charges lie- fore an administrative judge in Washington allegimg the companies sold coins which were not as high (nullity as advertised in their ca­ talogs 
Judge Suttle's order allowed owner Ronald 
L. (Hoper Io rev iew c f d iii to tile com­ panies tod receive any mail not pertaining to the alleged unlawful scheme. 
It the administrative law judge rules against 
Riverside and Security 
National, mail directed to the firms will he re­ turned to the sender. 
The president til the 
American Numismatic 
Assn testified during a hearing 
Friday the coms sold to postal m- 

Y i e t i i a m v e t 

 t o h e a t ! V A 
WASHINGTON (A P ) 
— President Carter said Friday he will nominate Max Cleland. a triple amputee in­ jured in the Vietnam war, to be administra­ tor of veterans affairs. 
Cleland, J4, a former 
Georgia state senator, is a staff member of the 
Senate Committee oil 
Veterans Affairs. 
He volunteered for 
Vietnam duty in 1987 and served with the 1st 
Air Cavalry Division for ll months. Shortly after promotion to captain, he was wounded by a grenade. He received the Brouze and Silver stars. 
Cleland. an Atlanta native, was once ap­ pointed by then-Gov 
Carter to a commission studying the problems of Vietnam veterans in 
Georgia. 

 specters by Riverside had been polished to make them appear to he higher quality. 
The administrative hearing is scheduled 
March 9. 
Cooper's attorney. 
Anthony Nicholas, said he would answer the 
Postal Service com­ plaint before the hear­ ing. 
He sought to delay the 
Friday hearing on the temporary order so he could prepare a de­ fense. 
"To grant this order would in effect put this man out of business." 
Nicholas said. 

Those charges in eluded falsely certify mg to student loan in-; stituttons that students 1 were enrolled and not refunding student tui-j 
{ions. 
Students should bej refunded any part of J their unused tuition,j according to state law. 
The attorney gener­ al's suit against 
Wehling involved Par­ ish Draughon’s Bu si­ ness College and Tech­ nical Institute in San 
Antonio and four other schools in Texas. 
Seven other schools 
Uehling owned are also involved. 
Students testify 

During the week-long trial of the suit against 
Uehling, the attorney general's office pre­ sented several former students of Wehling s school. 
They testified even though they attended the school for only a few days. Uehling never refunded the unused part of their tuitions. 
Most of the students had paid their tuitions with federal loans. 
A former business associate of U ehling al­ so testified Uehling's business practices in­ cluded not repaving student loans, not pa>4 ing tax withholdings arid the rapid transfer of school funds between hank accounts.

Police continued their search Friday for two knife wielding at­ tackers who fatally stabbed a young San 
Antonian. 

The victim, Johnny 
Salinas. 28. of IBIO EMI 
Fernando St., collapsed on a city bus in the 22181 block of Guadalupe 
Street Thursday night after flagging the vehi­ cle down, police said. 
Witnesses told police two men had chased the v u tim into an ice iiouse 

 where he was stubbed despite his efforts to fend them off with a beer Ixittle. 
After the pair fled.

BUENOS A IRES - A bomb blasted a 15-foot hole in an airport runway 
Friday, 2o seconds after a plane carrying Presi­ dent Jorge Videla and top aides lifted off from an adjacent strip. 
Videla arid the others were unhurt in the as­ sassination attempt, the third against the 
Argentine president, lie took over the presidency after Isabel Rerun was deposed last March. 
Hundreds of army troops and police quickly ringed the airport in northern Buenos Aires. which serves domestic flights. There were no immediate arrests and no other explosives were found

G EN EV A — The out­ look is bleak for the world’s social securitv systems, some of which have run up astronomical debts because ol global recession, according to a study by the Internation­ al Labor Organization. 
The stud.* said the U S expects Social Security fund assets to cover less than half the costs of the program this year while 
West Germany expects a deficit of $4 5 billion for pensions alone.
